词源上与拉丁语“obstinare”（坚持、顽固）有关，也和“stand（站立）”这种“站定不动”的意象相近：强调一个人立场很难动摇。

summary.en: “Obstipant” means “causing constipation,” used mainly in medical contexts.
summary.zh: “obstipant”意为“引起便秘的”，主要用于医学语境。

definition.en: causing constipation; making it hard to pass stool
definition.zh: （药物/食物等）引起便秘的；使排便困难的

examples.en: Some pain medicines can have an obstipant effect.
examples.zh: 一些止痛药可能会有引起便秘的作用。

examples.en: If this supplement feels obstipant, drink more water and talk to your doctor.
examples.zh: 如果这种补充剂让你觉得会引起便秘，多喝水并咨询医生。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较少见，多用于医学或药学语境。常见的替代表达有 constipating（引起便秘的）或 binding（使大便变干、难排的，较口语/传统用法）。
词源来自拉丁语前缀 ob-（加强/向…）+ stipare（塞满、挤紧），因此带有“把东西堵住、挤得很紧”的意象。

summary.en: “Obstipate” is a formal/medical word meaning to cause or become severely constipated.
summary.zh: “obstipate”是较正式/医学用语，表示使（或变得）严重便秘。

definition.en: to cause constipation; to make it difficult to pass stool
definition.zh: 使便秘；使排便困难

examples.en: Some pain medicines can obstipate you if you don’t drink enough water.
examples.zh: 有些止痛药如果你水喝不够，可能会让你便秘。

examples.en: Foods low in fiber may obstipate some people.
examples.zh: 低纤维的食物可能会让一些人便秘。

definition.en: to become severely constipated (a formal or medical use)
definition.zh: （变得）严重便秘（较正式/医学用语）

examples.en: After the surgery, he obstipated for several days and needed medical advice.
examples.zh: 手术后他严重便秘了好几天，需要医生建议。

definition.en: severely constipated (rare; usually replaced by “constipated”)
definition.zh: 严重便秘的（较少见；通常用 constipated）

examples.en: The doctor noted the patient was obstipate and uncomfortable.
examples.zh: 医生记录病人严重便秘且不适。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较少见、偏正式或医学语境。日常英语更常说：be constipated（便秘）、have constipation（有便秘）、be backed up（口语：堵住了/便秘）。
词源来自拉丁语 ob-（加强语气）+ stipare（挤压、塞满），所以有“被塞得很紧”→“排便不通”的感觉。
注意拼写：obstipate（动词/形容词）不要和 obstinate（固执的）混淆。

summary.en: Obstipated means severely constipated; figuratively, it can also mean extremely stubborn or unyielding.
summary.zh: obstipated 指“严重便秘的”；也可作比喻，指“极其顽固、不肯让步的”。

definition.en: Severely constipated; having great difficulty passing stool.
definition.zh: 严重便秘的；排便非常困难的。

examples.en: He felt obstipated after the long flight and eating too little fiber.
examples.zh: 长途飞行后再加上纤维吃得太少，他感觉严重便秘。

examples.en: If you’ve been obstipated for several days, it may be time to talk to a doctor.
examples.zh: 如果你已经严重便秘好几天了，可能该咨询医生了。

definition.en: (Figurative) Stubbornly refusing to change one’s opinion; extremely unyielding.
definition.zh: （比喻）顽固不化的；非常不肯让步的。

examples.en: The committee was obstipated and rejected every compromise.
examples.zh: 委员会非常顽固，否决了所有妥协方案。

examples.en: She can be obstipated about rules, even when they no longer make sense.
examples.zh: 即使规则已经不合时宜，她也可能对规则固执己见。

extraExplanation: 这个词较正式、偏书面或医学语境；日常口语里更常说 constipated（便秘的）或 badly constipated（严重便秘）。
比喻义源自“堵塞、难以排出”的身体状态，引申为“思想上堵住了、不肯改变”。
词源与拉丁语 obstipare（堵塞、阻塞）有关；因此常带有“堵得很厉害”的语感。

summary.en: Obstipation most commonly means severe constipation; more rarely, it can mean extreme stubbornness.
summary.zh: obstipation 最常指“严重便秘”；较少情况下也可指“极度固执”。

definition.en: Severe constipation: difficulty passing stool for a long time, often needing medical attention.
definition.zh: 严重便秘：长时间排便困难，常常需要医疗处理。

examples.en: After the surgery, he developed obstipation and had to see a doctor.
examples.zh: 手术后他出现了严重便秘，不得不去看医生。

examples.en: The nurse asked whether the patient had any bowel movements or signs of obstipation.
examples.zh: 护士询问病人是否有排便，或是否出现严重便秘的迹象。

definition.en: (Formal) Stubborn refusal to change your opinion; extreme stubbornness.
definition.zh: （正式）顽固不化；极度固执。

examples.en: Her obstipation made teamwork difficult.
examples.zh: 她的顽固让团队合作变得困难。

examples.en: He argued with obstipation, ignoring clear evidence.
examples.zh: 他固执地争辩，无视明显证据。

extraExplanation: 这个词在现代英语里最常见于医学语境，表示“严重便秘”。日常生活中更常说 constipation（便秘）。
第二个“固执”的意思源于拉丁语词根，和 obstinate（固执的）是同源词，但在当代使用频率较低、语气更正式。

summary.en: “Obstreperate” is usually a misspelling; the standard word is “obstreperous,” meaning noisy and hard to control.
summary.zh: “obstreperate”多为误拼；标准词是“obstreperous”，意思是“吵闹且难以管束”。

definition.en: Nonstandard or misspelled form; usually intended to mean “obstreperous” (noisy and difficult to control).
definition.zh: 非标准/常见拼写错误；通常想表达的是“obstreperous”（吵闹、难以管束的）。

examples.en: “Obstreperate” is often a misspelling of “obstreperous.”
examples.zh: “obstreperate”常常是“obstreperous”的误拼。

examples.en: The teacher asked the obstreperous students to calm down.
examples.zh: 老师让那些吵闹难管的学生安静下来。

definition.en: obstreperous: noisy, unruly, and hard to manage.
definition.zh: obstreperous：喧闹的、吵吵嚷嚷的、难以管束的。

examples.en: An obstreperous crowd gathered outside the stadium.
examples.zh: 一群喧闹的人聚集在体育场外。

examples.en: He was obstreperous in meetings, interrupting others constantly.
examples.zh: 他在会议上很难管束，总是不断打断别人。

extraExplanation: “obstreperous”更常见、也更标准；“obstreperate”一般不被当作正规英语单词使用。写作时建议用“obstreperous”。
词源上，“obstreperous”来自拉丁语，含有“喧闹、发出噪声”的意思，所以多用来形容人群、孩子、场面等“吵闹且不受控”。
搭配建议：obstreperous children/students/crowd；在语气上比“noisy”更强，强调“吵+难管”。

summary.en: “Obstreperosity” means loud, unruly behavior that is difficult to control.
summary.zh: “Obstreperosity”指又吵又不受控、难以管束的闹腾行为。

definition.en: noisy, rude, and hard-to-control behavior; rowdiness
definition.zh: 喧闹、粗鲁且难以管束的行为；吵闹/闹腾

examples.en: The teacher addressed the class’s obstreperosity before starting the lesson.
examples.zh: 老师在开始上课前先处理了全班的吵闹不守规矩。

examples.en: The meeting was delayed by the obstreperosity of a few angry guests.
examples.zh: 会议因几位愤怒来宾的喧闹争吵而被耽搁。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较书面、偏正式，常见于描述“吵闹失控的场面或行为”。日常口语里更常用 noisy, rowdy, unruly。
词源上来自拉丁语，含有“喧嚷/制造噪音（strep-）”的意味，因此既强调“声音大”，也强调“难管、爱闹”。

summary.en: Obstreperous means noisy, unruly, and hard to control.
summary.zh: Obstreperous 指“吵闹、难管束、不服从”的。

definition.en: Noisy and difficult to control; refusing to obey rules or authority (often describing a person, child, or group).
definition.zh: 吵闹且难以管束的；不服从（常形容人、孩子或一群人）。

examples.en: The teacher asked the obstreperous students to calm down and sit quietly.
examples.zh: 老师让那些吵闹难管的学生冷静下来，安静坐好。

examples.en: A few obstreperous fans disrupted the game by shouting insults.
examples.zh: 少数吵闹闹事的球迷用辱骂声干扰了比赛。

examples.en: He was obstreperous at the meeting, interrupting everyone and refusing to follow the agenda.
examples.zh: 他在会议上很闹腾，不断打断别人，还不肯按议程进行。

extraExplanation: 词源上来自拉丁语 *obstrepere*，意为“制造噪音、喧闹”。因此它不只是“生气/反对”，而是带有“吵闹、难以控制”的感觉。
语气通常偏负面，常见搭配：*obstreperous children/students/crowd*（难管的孩子/学生/人群）。
近义词区分：*rowdy* 更偏“喧闹放纵”；*defiant* 更偏“公然反抗”；*unruly* 更偏“难管、不守规矩”（不一定很吵）。

summary.en: Obstreperously means acting noisily and refusing to be controlled or corrected.
summary.zh: Obstreperously 指吵闹且不听管束、带对抗性地行动或回应。

definition.en: In a noisy, difficult-to-control way; behaving in a stubborn and unruly manner.
definition.zh: 吵闹且难以管束地；倔强、蛮横不听管教地。

examples.en: The students protested obstreperously outside the office.
examples.zh: 学生们在办公室外吵吵闹闹地抗议。

examples.en: He answered obstreperously when the teacher asked him to sit down.
examples.zh: 老师让他坐下时，他很不服气、蛮横地顶嘴。

extraExplanation: “obstreperously”来自形容词“obstreperous”（吵闹难管、蛮横的）。它常用于描述群体（如学生、抗议者、观众）发出喧闹声并且不配合管理的状态。
语气通常偏负面：不仅是“声音大”（noisy），还带有“难以控制/不服管”的意味；比“loudly”更强调对抗和不受约束。

summary.en: Obstreperousness means noisy, unruly behavior that is hard to control.
summary.zh: Obstreperousness 指“吵闹、难管束、不服从”的行为或状态。

definition.en: the quality of being noisy, difficult to control, and refusing to obey rules or authority
definition.zh: 吵闹又难以管束、抗拒规则或权威的特质；顽固不服管教

examples.en: The teacher handled the class’s obstreperousness by setting clear rules and staying calm.
examples.zh: 老师通过制定清晰的规则并保持冷静来应对全班的吵闹不服管教。

examples.en: His obstreperousness at the meeting made it hard to have a productive discussion.
examples.zh: 他在会议上的吵闹顶撞让讨论很难进行下去。

examples.en: The child’s obstreperousness eased after a quiet talk with a parent.
examples.zh: 孩子在和家长安静谈过之后就不那么闹腾顶撞了。

extraExplanation: 词根提示：obstreperous 来自拉丁语，含有“喧闹/吵闹”的意思；-ness 是常见名词后缀，表示“……的状态/性质”。所以 obstreperousness 就是“喧闹又不服管的状态”。
语体与搭配：多用于较正式的书面语或批评语境，常搭配 the obstreperousness of + 人/群体（如 children, protesters）。日常口语里也可用 noisiness（吵闹）或 unruliness（不守规矩）表达相近意思，但语气与侧重点略不同。

summary.en: “Obstreperousnesses” is the plural of “obstreperousness,” meaning instances or types of noisy, unruly, hard-to-control behavior.
summary.zh: “Obstreperousnesses”是“obstreperousness”的复数，指多次/多种吵闹、捣乱、难以管束的行为或表现。

definition.en: the quality or state of being noisy, stubborn, and hard to control; unruly behavior (plural form).
definition.zh: 吵闹、倔强且难以管束的状态；不守规矩的行为（复数形式）。

examples.en: The teacher addressed the obstreperousnesses in the classroom before starting the lesson.
examples.zh: 老师在开始上课前先处理了教室里那些吵闹捣乱的情况。

examples.en: The report compared different obstreperousnesses among the crowd at several events.
examples.zh: 报告比较了几个活动中人群不同程度的喧闹与失控行为。

extraExplanation: “obstreperousnesses”是名词“obstreperousness（吵闹、难管束）”的复数。这个复数形式在实际英语中很少见；多数情况下用不可数的“obstreperousness”来泛指这种“吵闹/捣乱”的特质。
词根提示：obstreperous（吵闹的、难管的）→ obstreperousness（名词：这种特质）→ obstreperousnesses（多个场合/多种表现形式的“吵闹难管”）。在学术写作里，复数有时用来强调“不同类型/多处发生的表现”。

summary.en: Obstriction means a blockage or obstruction; in older/medical use, it can mean constipation or intestinal blockage.
summary.zh: Obstriction 指“阻塞/梗阻、妨碍”；在较旧或医学用法中也可指“便秘或肠道梗阻”。

definition.en: a blockage or stopping of a passage, movement, or process; an obstruction.
definition.zh: 阻塞；梗阻；妨碍（使通道、运动或过程停止或受阻）。

examples.en: A landslide caused obstriction on the mountain road for two days.
examples.zh: 山体滑坡导致山路阻塞了两天。

examples.en: Poor planning can create obstriction in decision-making.
examples.zh: 糟糕的规划会造成决策过程受阻。

definition.en: (medical, less common) constipation or an intestinal blockage that prevents normal bowel movement.
definition.zh: （医学，较少见）便秘；肠道梗阻（使排便不畅或受阻）。

examples.en: The doctor asked whether the patient had any signs of obstriction.
examples.zh: 医生询问病人是否有便秘或梗阻的症状。

examples.en: Severe obstriction may require urgent treatment.
examples.zh: 严重的肠梗阻可能需要紧急治疗。

extraExplanation: “obstriction”在现代英语中非常少见，日常更常用的是“obstruction”（阻碍、障碍物）。
词源上与拉丁语 ob-（向着、对着）+ stringere（拉紧、束缚）有关，核心感觉是“把通道勒住/卡住”，因此引申为“阻塞”。
如果你在医学材料里看到它，多半是在较旧或较正式的写法中，指便秘或肠道梗阻；现代临床英语更常用 constipation / bowel obstruction。

summary.en: An archaic verb meaning “to bind/obligate” or “to restrain tightly.”
summary.zh: 一个很古老的动词，意为“使负有义务/受约束”，也可指“捆紧、束缚”。

definition.en: (Archaic) to bind or obligate someone; to place someone under a duty (often by a promise, oath, or law).
definition.zh: （古义）使（某人）受约束／负有义务；（常指因承诺、誓言或法律而）使承担责任。

examples.en: The contract obstringes both parties to keep the information confidential.
examples.zh: 这份合同约束双方必须对信息保密。

examples.en: By his oath, he was obstringed to tell the truth.
examples.zh: 由于宣誓，他被约束必须说真话。

definition.en: (Archaic) to tie up or fasten tightly; to restrain.
definition.zh: （古义）捆紧、系牢；限制、束缚。

examples.en: The vines seemed to obstringe the old gate.
examples.zh: 藤蔓仿佛把旧大门紧紧缠住。

examples.en: Fear can obstringe the mind and stop clear thinking.
examples.zh: 恐惧会束缚心智，使人难以清晰思考。

extraExplanation: “obstringe”在现代英语中非常罕见，多见于早期法律、神学或修辞性写作。现代更常用的表达是“bind / obligate / constrain / restrain”。
词源来自拉丁语 *obstringere*（*ob-* 表“向、加于……之上”，*stringere* 表“拉紧、束紧”），因此它既有“法律/道德上的约束”，也有“物理上的捆束”两层含义。

summary.en: Obstruct means to block a path or to hinder progress, sometimes deliberately (especially in formal or legal contexts).
summary.zh: Obstruct 指“阻挡道路/视线”等使通行困难，也可指（多用于正式或法律语境）“阻挠、妨碍”使进展不顺。

definition.en: to block or get in the way of something, so movement or progress becomes difficult or impossible
definition.zh: 阻挡；妨碍（使通行或进展变得困难或不可能）

examples.en: A parked truck obstructed the entrance to the building.
examples.zh: 一辆停着的卡车堵住了大楼入口。

examples.en: Please don’t obstruct the aisle; people need to pass through.
examples.zh: 请不要挡住过道；大家需要通行。

examples.en: Heavy smoke can obstruct your view while driving.
examples.zh: 浓烟会在开车时遮挡视线。

definition.en: to deliberately prevent something (such as a process, investigation, or plan) from happening smoothly
definition.zh: （故意）阻挠；干扰（使过程、调查或计划无法顺利进行）

examples.en: It is illegal to obstruct a police investigation.
examples.zh: 妨碍警方调查是违法的。

examples.en: He was accused of obstructing justice.
examples.zh: 他被指控妨碍司法公正。

extraExplanation: “obstruct”常用于较正式的语境（如新闻、法律、公告）。日常口语里，表示“挡住路”更常说block / get in the way。
常见搭配：obstruct traffic（阻碍交通）、obstruct the view（遮挡视线）、obstruct justice（妨碍司法，法律用语）。
词源提示：来自拉丁语 ob-（对着、反对）+ struere（建造、堆起），原意有“在前面堆东西以阻挡”的画面感。

summary.en: “Obstructant” means something that blocks or hinders; it can be a noun (a blocker) or an adjective (blocking).
summary.zh: “Obstructant”表示“阻碍/堵塞的东西”，可作名词（阻碍物）或形容词（阻塞性的）。

definition.en: Something (or someone) that blocks, hinders, or gets in the way; an obstructing agent.
definition.zh: 阻碍物；妨碍者（指造成阻挡或妨碍的事物或人）。

examples.en: Mucus can act as an obstructant in the airway during a severe cold.
examples.zh: 在重感冒时，黏液可能成为气道中的阻碍物。

examples.en: In the debate, constant interruptions became an obstructant to productive discussion.
examples.zh: 在辩论中，不断的打断成了有效讨论的阻碍。

definition.en: Blocking or preventing movement, progress, or flow; obstructing.
definition.zh: 造成阻塞的；妨碍的；阻挡的。

examples.en: The report mentioned obstructant tissue that was narrowing the passage.
examples.zh: 报告提到有阻塞性组织使通道变窄。

examples.en: They removed the obstructant debris from the drain.
examples.zh: 他们清除了下水道里造成堵塞的碎屑。

extraExplanation: “Obstructant”较少见，尤其在日常英语里不常用；更常见的替代说法是名词“obstruction”“blockage”，或形容词“obstructive”。
构词：来自动词“obstruct（阻碍、阻塞）”加上后缀“-ant”（表示“……者/……物”或“具有……性质的”），因此既可作名词也可作形容词。
在医学、工程或技术写作中更可能出现，用来强调“造成堵塞/妨碍的东西或因素”。

summary.en: Obstructed means blocked or made difficult to pass, see, or do; it can describe a state (adj.) or the result of blocking (past of obstruct).
summary.zh: obstructed 表示“被阻塞/受阻”，可作形容词描述状态，也可作动词 obstruct 的过去式/过去分词表示“造成阻挡的结果”。

definition.en: Blocked or made difficult to pass through, see, or do.
definition.zh: 被阻塞的；受阻的；难以通过、看清或进行的。

examples.en: The road is obstructed by fallen trees after the storm.
examples.zh: 暴风雨过后，道路被倒下的树木阻塞了。

examples.en: My view was obstructed, so I moved to the front row.
examples.zh: 我的视线被挡住了，所以我移到了前排。

examples.en: Breathing can feel obstructed when you have a bad cold.
examples.zh: 重感冒时，你可能会感觉呼吸不畅（受阻）。

definition.en: Past form of “obstruct”: to block a path, progress, or activity; to get in the way.
definition.zh: “obstruct”的过去式/过去分词：阻挡（道路、进展或活动）；妨碍。

examples.en: A parked truck obstructed the entrance to the building.
examples.zh: 一辆停着的卡车堵住了大楼入口。

examples.en: The protest obstructed traffic for hours.
examples.zh: 抗议活动使交通受阻了好几个小时。

extraExplanation: “obstructed”既可作形容词（表示“处于被阻挡的状态”），也可作动词的过去式/过去分词（强调“谁/什么造成了阻挡”）。常见搭配有：obstructed view（视线受阻）、obstructed airway（气道阻塞）、obstructed traffic（交通受阻）。
语气上“obstruct”比“block”更正式一些，也常用于法律/新闻语境，如 obstruct justice（妨碍司法）。

summary.en: “Obstructedly” means “in a blocked/impeded way” or “in a way that blocks or hinders,” but it is rare; common alternatives are “in an obstructed way” or “in the way.”
summary.zh: “obstructedly”表示“以受阻的方式”或“以造成阻碍的方式”，但很少用；更常见的说法是“in an obstructed way”或“in the way”。

definition.en: In a blocked or impeded way; with something in the way so movement, progress, or view is not clear or easy.
definition.zh: 以受阻的方式；有东西挡着，使移动、进展或视线不顺畅。

examples.en: The path was obstructedly narrow, forcing hikers to walk single file.
examples.zh: 这条小路狭窄且受阻，迫使徒步者只能排成一列走。

examples.en: His voice came obstructedly through the closed door and loud music.
examples.zh: 隔着紧闭的门和嘈杂的音乐，他的声音断断续续地传来。

definition.en: In a way that causes obstruction; so as to block or hinder something.
definition.zh: 以造成阻碍的方式；用来阻挡或妨碍某事。

examples.en: The furniture was placed obstructedly, blocking the hallway.
examples.zh: 家具摆放得很碍事，把走廊堵住了。

examples.en: She stood obstructedly in front of the screen, so people couldn’t see.
examples.zh: 她挡在屏幕前站着，大家都看不见。

extraExplanation: “obstructedly”非常少见，更常用、更自然的表达是：**in an obstructed way / in a way that obstructs**，或直接用常见副词/短语替换，如 **awkwardly, in the way, blocking the way, with difficulty**。
构词：**obstruct**（阻碍）→ **obstructed**（受阻的/被挡住的）→ **obstructedly**（副词）。写作中若追求自然地道，通常避免使用这个较生硬的派生副词。

summary.en: An obstructer is a person who blocks progress or physically gets in the way; the more common spelling is “obstructor.”
summary.zh: obstructer 指阻挠进展或在物理上挡路的人；更常见的拼写是 obstructor。

definition.en: A person who deliberately blocks, delays, or makes it difficult for something to happen; someone who gets in the way.
definition.zh: 阻挠者；妨碍者：故意阻挡、拖延或让事情更难发生的人。

examples.en: The meeting was delayed by an obstructer who kept interrupting every speaker.
examples.zh: 会议被一位不断打断每位发言者的阻挠者拖延了。

examples.en: Some saw him as an obstructer of reform, not a helpful critic.
examples.zh: 一些人把他视为改革的阻挠者，而不是有帮助的批评者。

definition.en: Someone who physically blocks a path, entrance, or view.
definition.zh: （物理上）堵塞通道/入口/视线的人。

examples.en: A protester stood in the doorway as an obstructer, stopping people from entering.
examples.zh: 一名抗议者站在门口充当堵门者，阻止人们进入。

examples.en: The security guard asked the obstructer to move away from the emergency exit.
examples.zh: 保安要求堵在紧急出口旁的人让开。

extraExplanation: “obstructer”是可用的拼写，但更常见、更标准的形式是“obstructor”。在法律或正式语境中也可能见到“obstructionist”（指“惯于阻挠的人”，常用于政治或立法程序）。
词根来自拉丁语 ob-（向着、对着）+ struere（建造、堆起），原义带有“在前面堆起东西以阻挡”的感觉。

summary.en: “Obstructers” means people or things that block or hinder; the more common spelling is “obstructors.”
summary.zh: “obstructers” 指阻碍或妨碍的人/物；更常见的拼写是 “obstructors”。

definition.en: people or things that block, hinder, or get in the way of progress or movement (plural of *obstructer*)
definition.zh: 阻碍者；妨碍物（*obstructer* 的复数）

examples.en: The project slowed down because of a few obstructers who refused to share information.
examples.zh: 项目进展变慢，是因为有几个阻碍者拒绝分享信息。

examples.en: Remove any obstructers from the hallway to keep the exit clear.
examples.zh: 把走廊里的妨碍物移开，保持出口畅通。

extraExplanation: “obstructers” 来自动词 *obstruct*（阻碍）。不过在现代英语里，更常见、更标准的名词是 **obstructors**（阻碍者）或 **obstacles**（障碍物）。如果你写作或考试，通常建议用 **obstructors**。

summary.en: “Obstructing” means blocking or getting in the way, preventing movement or progress.
summary.zh: “Obstructing”表示阻挡、妨碍，使通行或进展不顺。

definition.en: blocking a path, view, or process; preventing something from moving or happening smoothly (present participle of “obstruct”).
definition.zh: 阻挡（道路/视线/进程）；妨碍某事顺利进行（“obstruct”的现在分词）。

examples.en: A fallen tree was obstructing the road, so cars had to turn back.
examples.zh: 一棵倒下的树挡住了道路，所以车辆不得不掉头。

examples.en: Please stop obstructing the doorway—people need to get through.
examples.zh: 请不要堵在门口——大家需要通行。

examples.en: Loud noise was obstructing our conversation.
examples.zh: 噪音妨碍了我们的谈话。

definition.en: acting as an obstacle; getting in the way (used like an adjective).
definition.zh: 起阻碍作用的；挡路的（作形容词用）。

examples.en: Remove any obstructing objects before you open the emergency exit.
examples.zh: 打开紧急出口前，请移除任何挡路的物品。

examples.en: The camera couldn’t focus because of obstructing branches.
examples.zh: 因为有树枝遮挡，摄像机无法对焦。

extraExplanation: “obstructing”常见搭配：obstructing traffic（妨碍交通）、obstructing justice（妨碍司法/阻挠执法）、obstructing the view（遮挡视线）。在新闻或法律语境里很常见。
语气通常偏正式，比“blocking”更强调“造成阻碍/带来麻烦”，有时暗示故意或不当行为。

summary.en: “Obstructingly” means “in a way that blocks or hinders,” but it is uncommon; “obstructively” is more natural.
summary.zh: obstructingly 表示“以阻碍/妨碍的方式”，但较少见；更常用的是 obstructively 或 in an obstructive way。

definition.en: In a way that blocks, hinders, or gets in the way of something.
definition.zh: 以阻挡、妨碍或造成障碍的方式。

examples.en: Boxes were piled obstructingly in the hallway, so people had to squeeze past.
examples.zh: 箱子在走廊里堆得很碍事，所以人们不得不挤着过去。

examples.en: He spoke obstructingly, interrupting others and slowing down the discussion.
examples.zh: 他讲话很“碍事”，总打断别人，让讨论进展变慢。

extraExplanation: “obstructingly”是由动词 obstruct（阻碍、妨碍）+ 副词后缀 -ingly 构成，但在现代英语里比较少见。更自然、常用的表达通常是 “in an obstructive way” 或直接用副词 “obstructively”。

summary.en: Obstruction means a blockage or something that gets in the way, or the act of deliberately hindering (often in law/politics).
summary.zh: obstruction 指“阻碍/障碍（物）”或“阻挠（行为）”，也可指医学上的“阻塞/梗阻”。

definition.en: Something that blocks, slows, or gets in the way of movement, progress, or understanding.
definition.zh: 阻碍物；障碍（指挡住、减慢或妨碍行动、进展或理解的事物）。

examples.en: There was an obstruction in the road, so traffic had to stop.
examples.zh: 路上有障碍物，所以车辆不得不停下来。

examples.en: Lack of clear information can be an obstruction to good decision-making.
examples.zh: 信息不清楚会成为做出好决定的障碍。

definition.en: The act of deliberately preventing something from happening or making it difficult, often in a legal or political context.
definition.zh: （常指法律或政治语境中）阻挠；妨碍（故意让某事难以进行或无法发生的行为）。

examples.en: The judge warned that any obstruction of justice could lead to serious penalties.
examples.zh: 法官警告，任何妨碍司法的行为都可能导致严重处罚。

examples.en: They accused him of obstruction during the investigation.
examples.zh: 他们指控他在调查过程中进行阻挠。

definition.en: A medical blockage in the body, such as in the airway or intestines.
definition.zh: （医学）阻塞；梗阻（如气道或肠道的堵塞）。

examples.en: The doctor checked for airway obstruction.
examples.zh: 医生检查是否存在气道阻塞。

examples.en: Intestinal obstruction can cause severe abdominal pain.
examples.zh: 肠梗阻会引起严重腹痛。

extraExplanation: “Obstruction”来自拉丁语 obstruere（意为“堵住、阻塞”），因此既可指具体的“挡路之物”，也可指抽象的“阻挠行为”。
常见搭配：an obstruction to progress（进步的障碍）；remove/clear an obstruction（清除障碍）；obstruction of justice（妨碍司法，法律固定搭配）。

summary.en: Obstructionism is the deliberate practice of blocking or slowing progress, especially in politics.
summary.zh: Obstructionism 指故意阻挠或拖延进展的做法，尤用于政治语境。

definition.en: the act of deliberately preventing progress, discussion, or decision-making (especially in politics) by causing delays or creating difficulties
definition.zh: （尤指政治上）故意阻挠、拖延进程或决策的行为

examples.en: The bill failed after weeks of obstructionism in the legislature.
examples.zh: 由于议会里连续数周的阻挠，这项法案最终未能通过。

examples.en: Critics said the party’s obstructionism kept the government from addressing the crisis.
examples.zh: 批评者说，该党的阻挠行为使政府无法处理这场危机。

extraExplanation: 这个词常用于政治语境，强调“有意为之”的拖延与阻挠，而不只是一般的“反对”。
在美国政治里常见相关表达有 filibuster（冗长发言拖延表决，尤指参议院程序）和 stonewall（“筑墙”式拖延或拒不配合）。
词根提示：obstruct（阻碍）+ -ism（某种做法/主义），因此 obstructionism 常带有负面评价色彩。

summary.en: An obstructionist is someone—or something—that deliberately blocks or slows progress, especially in politics.
summary.zh: obstructionist 指故意阻挠或拖延进展的人（或带阻挠性质的做法/态度），尤常见于政治语境。

definition.en: A person who deliberately tries to stop or slow down progress, decisions, or changes (especially in politics or group work).
definition.zh: （尤指政治或团体中）故意阻挠、拖延进展或决策的人。

examples.en: Some lawmakers called him an obstructionist for blocking the vote again and again.
examples.zh: 一些立法者称他为“阻挠者”，因为他一再阻止表决。

examples.en: In the meeting, she wasn’t offering solutions—she was acting like an obstructionist.
examples.zh: 在会议上，她没有提出解决方案——她的表现更像是在故意阻挠。

definition.en: Deliberately trying to prevent progress or delay action.
definition.zh: （行为或态度）故意阻挠的；拖延的。

examples.en: The senator took an obstructionist stance on the reform bill.
examples.zh: 这位参议员对改革法案采取了阻挠立场。

examples.en: Obstructionist tactics can make even simple decisions take weeks.
examples.zh: 阻挠性策略会让即使很简单的决定也拖上好几周。

extraExplanation: 这个词常用于政治语境，尤其是描述通过程序手段“拖延/卡住”议程的人或做法；常和“filibuster（冗长辩论以拖延表决）”这一美国政治术语联系在一起。
构词：obstruct（阻碍）+ -ion（名词后缀）→ obstruction（阻碍）+ -ist（某类人/支持者）→ obstructionist（阻挠者）。语气通常带批评。

summary.en: “Obstructionistic” describes someone or something that deliberately blocks or delays progress, especially in politics or meetings.
summary.zh: “obstructionistic”指故意阻挠或拖延进展的（尤用于政治或会议语境）。

definition.en: Deliberately trying to block or delay progress, discussion, or decision-making—especially in politics or formal meetings.
definition.zh: （尤指在政治或正式会议中）故意阻挠、拖延进程或决策的。

examples.en: The senator was criticized for taking an obstructionistic approach to the bill.
examples.zh: 这位参议员因对该法案采取阻挠式做法而受到批评。

examples.en: Obstructionistic tactics in the meeting prevented the team from reaching a decision.
examples.zh: 会议上的阻挠策略让团队无法做出决定。

definition.en: Creating obstacles or making cooperation difficult in everyday situations; unhelpfully resistant.
definition.zh: （在日常情境中）制造障碍、使合作变困难的；不必要地抵制的。

examples.en: His obstructionistic attitude made it hard to finish the project on time.
examples.zh: 他那种处处阻挠的态度让项目很难按时完成。

examples.en: Instead of being obstructionistic, try suggesting a workable alternative.
examples.zh: 与其处处阻挠，不如提出一个可行的替代方案。

extraExplanation: “obstructionistic”常用于带批评色彩的语境，尤其是新闻与政治评论中，表示“为了反对而反对”，而不一定提出建设性方案。
相关常见词：obstructionist（n./adj. 阻挠者/阻挠的）；obstructionism（n. 阻挠主义、拖延战术）。
在美国政治语境里，它常和“filibuster（冗长辩论以拖延表决）”等议事策略一起出现。

summary.en: “Obstructionists” are people who deliberately block or delay progress, especially in politics.
summary.zh: “obstructionists”指故意阻碍或拖延进展的人，尤用于政治语境。

definition.en: People who intentionally block, delay, or prevent progress—especially in politics or group decision-making.
definition.zh: 阻挠者；捣乱者（尤指在政治或集体决策中故意阻止、拖延进展的人）

examples.en: The bill failed because a small group of obstructionists kept delaying the vote.
examples.zh: 这项法案未能通过，因为一小群阻挠者不断拖延表决。

examples.en: Some saw the protesters as obstructionists; others saw them as defenders of public safety.
examples.zh: 有人把抗议者视为阻挠者；也有人认为他们是在维护公共安全。

extraExplanation: “Obstructionist”常用于政治语境，指通过程序手段或不断提出反对意见来“拖住”议程的人。在美国政治里，它有时会和参议院的“冗长辩论（filibuster）”联系在一起，但更广义地也可用于任何组织、会议或项目中故意让事情难以推进的人。
语气通常偏负面，暗示对方不是在提出建设性批评，而是在“故意卡关”。如果想更中性一些，可以用“opponents（反对者）/ critics（批评者）”。

summary.en: “Obstructions” means obstacles or blocking actions that stop movement or progress.
summary.zh: “obstructions”指阻碍通行或进展的障碍物，也可指人为的阻挠行为。

definition.en: things that block a path, passage, or process; obstacles
definition.zh: 阻挡通道或进程的东西；障碍物

examples.en: A fallen tree caused obstructions on the road.
examples.zh: 倒下的树造成了道路上的障碍。

examples.en: Please remove any obstructions from the hallway for safety.
examples.zh: 为安全起见，请清除走廊里的障碍物。

examples.en: Narrow streets and parked cars create obstructions for buses.
examples.zh: 狭窄的街道和停放的车辆会阻碍公交车通行。

definition.en: actions or behaviors that intentionally slow down, block, or prevent progress (often in work, rules, or law)
definition.zh: （常指在工作、制度或法律中）故意拖延、阻挠或妨碍进展的行为

examples.en: The project faced repeated obstructions from unnecessary paperwork.
examples.zh: 这个项目因不必要的文书手续而一再受阻。

examples.en: They accused him of creating obstructions during the meeting.
examples.zh: 他们指责他在会议中制造阻挠。

examples.en: In some countries, “obstruction of justice” is a serious crime.
examples.zh: 在一些国家，“妨碍司法公正”是严重犯罪。

extraExplanation: “Obstructions”是名词复数，单数是“obstruction”。在医学语境里也常见，如“airway obstruction（气道阻塞）”“bowel obstruction（肠梗阻）”，表示身体通道被堵塞。

summary.en: Obstructive means blocking progress or movement; in medicine, it describes conditions that cause physical blockage (like airflow).
summary.zh: obstructive 指“阻碍的/妨碍的”；在医学上指“阻塞性的”，强调通道被堵（如气流受阻）。

definition.en: Blocking or making it difficult for something to move, happen, or be done.
definition.zh: 阻碍的；妨碍的；使事情难以进行的。

examples.en: The fallen tree was obstructive and blocked the road.
examples.zh: 倒下的树很碍事，把路堵住了。

examples.en: Please don’t be obstructive—let’s find a solution together.
examples.zh: 请不要故意刁难——我们一起想办法解决。

definition.en: (Medical) Relating to a condition that blocks a passage in the body (such as airflow in the lungs).
definition.zh: （医学）阻塞性的；与身体通道被堵塞有关的（如气道受阻）。

examples.en: He was diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea.
examples.zh: 他被诊断为阻塞性睡眠呼吸暂停。

examples.en: Obstructive lung disease can make breathing difficult.
examples.zh: 阻塞性肺病会使呼吸变得困难。

extraExplanation: “obstructive”来自动词“obstruct”（阻挡、妨碍）。日常用法里常带有“故意不配合、制造障碍”的语气，常见搭配有：obstructive behavior（阻挠行为）、obstructive attitude（对抗/不合作的态度）。
医学语境中，“obstructive”常与“restrictive（限制性）”对比：obstructive强调“通道被堵导致气流/血流不畅”，restrictive强调“容量变小、扩张受限”。

summary.en: “Obstructively” means doing something in a way that blocks or hinders progress.
summary.zh: “obstructively”表示以阻碍、妨碍进展的方式行事或发生。

definition.en: In a way that blocks, hinders, or makes progress difficult (physically or figuratively).
definition.zh: 以阻碍的方式；以妨碍、阻挠进展的方式（可指实际或比喻）。

examples.en: A truck was parked obstructively, blocking the entrance to the building.
examples.zh: 一辆卡车停得很妨碍通行，把大楼入口堵住了。

examples.en: He spoke obstructively during the meeting, interrupting others and slowing decisions.
examples.zh: 他在会议上发言很“阻挠式”，不断打断别人，拖慢了决策。

extraExplanation: “obstructively”来自形容词“obstructive（妨碍的/阻挠的）+ -ly”。日常写作里更常用更自然的表达是“in an obstructive way / in a way that blocks/hinders…”。

summary.en: Obstructiveness means a tendency to create obstacles or refuse to cooperate; less commonly, it can mean a physical state of being blocked.
summary.zh: Obstructiveness 指“爱阻挠、不合作、制造困难”的倾向；较少见时也可指“（通道等）阻塞的状态”。

definition.en: The quality of being difficult, uncooperative, or likely to cause delays by refusing to help or by creating obstacles.
definition.zh: （人或行为的）阻挠性；不合作、故意制造困难或拖延的特质。

examples.en: The meeting went nowhere because of his obstructiveness.
examples.zh: 因为他的阻挠，会议毫无进展。

examples.en: Managers complained about obstructiveness from a few team members during the change process.
examples.zh: 在变革过程中，经理们抱怨少数成员表现出阻挠和不配合。

definition.en: The state of being physically blocked or partially blocked (less common in everyday English).
definition.zh: （较少见）阻塞状态；（通道、气流等）被堵住或部分堵住。

examples.en: The doctor noted obstructiveness in the patient’s airway during the exam.
examples.zh: 医生在检查时注意到病人的气道有阻塞情况。

examples.en: Dust can increase the obstructiveness of a filter over time.
examples.zh: 灰尘会随着时间增加滤网的阻塞程度。

extraExplanation: “obstructiveness”来自动词“obstruct”（阻碍、妨碍）+ 名词后缀“-ness”（表示性质/状态）。日常语境里更常指人的态度或做事方式“爱阻挠、难配合”。医学或技术语境中偶尔用来描述“阻塞程度/阻力增加”。
相关词：obstruction（障碍物/阻塞/妨碍）, obstructive（阻碍的；阻塞性的）。常见搭配：obstructive behavior（阻挠行为）, obstructiveness in negotiations（谈判中的阻挠态度）。

summary.en: Obstructivism means deliberately blocking or delaying progress, especially in politics.
summary.zh: Obstructivism 指故意阻挠或拖延进展的做法，尤用于政治语境。

definition.en: the practice or policy of deliberately blocking or delaying actions, decisions, or progress (especially in politics or organizations)
definition.zh: （尤指在政治或组织中）故意阻挠、拖延决策或进展的做法/政策

examples.en: Some critics accused the party of obstructivism during the budget talks.
examples.zh: 一些批评者指责该党在预算谈判中采取阻挠主义。

examples.en: Obstructivism can slow down reforms that many people support.
examples.zh: 阻挠主义会拖慢许多人支持的改革。

extraExplanation: “obstructivism”较少见，更常用的是“obstructionism”（阻挠主义）。两者意思非常接近，日常新闻与学术讨论中通常优先用“obstructionism”。
词源上来自“obstruct”（阻挡）+ “-ivism”（表示一种做法/倾向）。常见搭配有“political obstructivism”“legislative obstructivism”等。
在英美政治语境里，它常与“filibuster”（冗长辩论以拖延表决，常译“阻挠议事/拉布”）相关，但“filibuster”更特指议会程序手段，而“obstructivism/obstructionism”更泛指整体策略或态度。

summary.en: Obstructivity means the degree or tendency of something to block or hinder, especially in technical or medical writing.
summary.zh: Obstructivity 指“阻塞/阻碍的程度或倾向”，多见于技术或医学写作。

definition.en: the tendency or ability to obstruct; the degree to which something blocks or hinders a flow, passage, or process (often used in technical/medical contexts)
definition.zh: 阻塞性；阻碍性；（常用于技术/医学语境）指某物造成阻塞、妨碍流动或通行的倾向或程度

examples.en: Doctors measured the patient’s airway obstructivity to understand how serious the breathing problem was.
examples.zh: 医生测量了病人的气道阻塞程度，以判断呼吸问题有多严重。

examples.en: Filters are rated by how much obstructivity they add to airflow.
examples.zh: 滤网常按它们对气流增加了多少阻塞来评级。

extraExplanation: “obstructivity”在日常英语里不常用，更常见的是用“obstruction（阻塞/阻碍）”“blockage（堵塞）”“resistance（阻力）”或形容词“obstructive（阻塞性的）”。
构词：obstruct（阻塞）+ -ive（…的）+ -ity（…性/性质）。在医学里常见于与呼吸相关的表达，如“airway obstructivity（气道阻塞性/阻塞程度）”。

summary.en: An obstructor is someone or something that blocks or slows progress.
summary.zh: obstructor 指阻挡或拖慢进展的人或事物（阻碍者/妨碍物）。

definition.en: a person or thing that blocks, hinders, or gets in the way of progress or movement
definition.zh: 阻碍者；妨碍物（指阻挡、拖延或妨碍进展/行动的人或事物）

examples.en: In the debate, she called the senator an obstructor of reform.
examples.zh: 在辩论中，她称那位参议员是改革的阻碍者。

examples.en: A fallen tree became an obstructor on the road, stopping traffic.
examples.zh: 一棵倒下的树成了路上的阻碍物，导致车辆无法通行。

examples.en: He tried not to be an obstructor and offered help instead of criticism.
examples.zh: 他尽量不当“绊脚石”，而是用帮助代替批评。

extraExplanation: “Obstructor”来自拉丁语词根 *struct*（“建造、结构”）与前缀 *ob-*（“朝向、对着；阻挡”），字面含义接近“站在前面挡住的人/物”。
在正式语境里，它可用于描述政治或程序上的“阻挠者”（比如拖延议事、阻挡立法的人）。日常口语中更常用 *obstacle*（障碍）、*blocker*（阻挡者/阻碍因素）或 *someone who gets in the way*（碍事的人）。

summary.en: “Obstructors” is the plural of “obstructor”: people or things that block or hinder progress.
summary.zh: “obstructors”是“obstructor”的复数：指阻挡或妨碍进展的人或事物。

definition.en: A person or thing that blocks, gets in the way, or makes progress difficult; someone who deliberately creates obstacles.
definition.zh: 阻挡者；制造障碍的人（或事物）；故意设置阻碍的人。

examples.en: The plan failed because a few obstructors kept delaying every decision.
examples.zh: 计划失败了，因为有几个人一直拖延每一个决定，制造阻碍。

examples.en: In the narrow hallway, the boxes became obstructors to everyone trying to pass.
examples.zh: 在狭窄的走廊里，那些箱子成了大家通行的障碍物。

extraExplanation: “obstructor”来自动词“obstruct”（阻碍、妨碍）。在正式或书面语中更常见，也可能出现在法律/公共事务语境里，指“阻挠者、妨害者”。口语里常用“blocker”或“someone who gets in the way”。

summary.en: “Obstructs” means blocks something physically or gets in the way of a process, usually making movement or progress harder.
summary.zh: “Obstructs”表示在物理上阻挡，或在事情进展上设置阻碍，使通行或进展更困难。

definition.en: to block a road, path, view, or passage so that movement or progress is difficult or impossible
definition.zh: 阻挡（道路、通道、视线等），使通行或进展变得困难或不可能

examples.en: A parked truck obstructs the narrow street.
examples.zh: 一辆停着的卡车堵住了狭窄的街道。

examples.en: Too many pop-up windows obstruct the view of the article.
examples.zh: 太多弹窗挡住了文章内容。

definition.en: to deliberately interfere with a process, plan, or person to prevent success
definition.zh: （故意）妨碍、阻挠（流程、计划或他人），使其难以成功

examples.en: He obstructs the investigation by refusing to answer basic questions.
examples.zh: 他拒绝回答基本问题，从而妨碍调查。

examples.en: Loud arguments can obstruct teamwork.
examples.zh: 大声争吵会妨碍团队合作。

extraExplanation: “obstructs”是动词“obstruct”的第三人称单数现在时（he/she/it obstructs）。常见搭配：obstruct traffic（阻塞交通）、obstruct the view（挡住视线）、obstruct justice/an investigation（妨碍司法/调查）。在正式语境中也常见名词形式“obstruction”（阻碍、堵塞）。

summary.en: An obstruent is a consonant made with significant airflow obstruction; the word can be a noun or an adjective in linguistics.
summary.zh: obstruent 指“阻音”：发音时气流明显受阻的辅音；在语言学中可作名词或形容词。

definition.en: (Linguistics) A consonant sound made by blocking or strongly narrowing the airflow (for example, stops, fricatives, and affricates).
definition.zh: （语言学）阻音；指通过阻塞或强烈收窄气流而发出的辅音（如塞音、擦音、塞擦音）。

examples.en: English /p/ and /t/ are obstruents because the airflow is blocked completely.
examples.zh: 英语中的 /p/ 和 /t/ 是阻音，因为气流被完全阻塞。

examples.en: Many languages contrast obstruents with sonorants like /m/ and /l/.
examples.zh: 许多语言会把阻音与响音（如 /m/、/l/）区分开来。

definition.en: (Linguistics) Describing a consonant produced with an obstruction in the vocal tract.
definition.zh: （语言学）阻音的；指发音时声道气流受到阻碍的（辅音）。

examples.en: In phonology class, we studied obstruent consonants such as /s/ and /k/.
examples.zh: 在音系学课上，我们学习了像 /s/ 和 /k/ 这样的阻音辅音。

extraExplanation: “obstruent”来自拉丁语词根，和“obstruct（阻碍）”同源，因此很好记：发音时气流被“阻碍”。
在入门语音学里，常见的二分法是：obstruents（阻音：塞音/擦音/塞擦音） vs. sonorants（响音：鼻音、流音、近音等）。阻音更容易出现“清浊”对立（如 /s/ vs. /z/）。

summary.en: Obstruse means ‘difficult to understand,’ especially because the wording or explanation is unclear or overly complex.
summary.zh: Obstruse 指“晦涩难懂”，尤指因措辞或解释过于复杂、不清楚而难以理解。

definition.en: Hard to understand because it is expressed in a complicated, unclear, or overly academic way.
definition.zh: （因表达复杂、晦涩或过于学术化而）难以理解的；晦涩难懂的。

examples.en: The professor’s explanation was so obstruse that many students gave up taking notes.
examples.zh: 教授的解释太晦涩了，很多学生干脆放弃记笔记。

examples.en: Legal documents can be obstruse, so it helps to read them slowly.
examples.zh: 法律文件可能很晦涩，所以慢慢读会更有帮助。

examples.en: The article isn’t wrong—it’s just obstruse.
examples.zh: 这篇文章并非不对——只是写得太晦涩。

extraExplanation: “obstruse”较少见，更常用的近义词是“obscure / complicated / hard to understand”。写作中用它通常带有批评意味：不是内容深，而是表达让人难懂。
易与“obtuse（迟钝的；不敏锐的）”混淆：obstruse形容“文字/表达/概念”难懂；obtuse更常形容“人/反应”不够敏锐。
词源来自拉丁语，含有“阻塞、挡住”的意思，可联想为“意思被挡住了，所以看不清、读不懂”。

summary.en: *Obstruxit* is a Latin form meaning “(he/she/it) blocked or obstructed,” mainly seen when quoting Latin texts.
summary.zh: *Obstruxit* 是拉丁语形式，意思是“（他/她/它）堵住了、阻塞了”，主要用于引用拉丁原文时。

definition.en: (Latin) “blocked; obstructed; built up or closed off.” It is the simple past (perfect) form of the Latin verb *obstruere* (“to block/obstruct”).
definition.zh: （拉丁语）“堵住了；阻塞了；封住了。”它是拉丁动词 *obstruere*（“阻塞/堵住”）的完成时（相当于简单过去时）形式。

examples.en: In the manuscript, the scribe writes *obstruxit*, meaning “he blocked the passage.”
examples.zh: 在手稿里，抄写员写下 *obstruxit*，意思是“他堵住了通道”。

examples.en: The note says the river was *obstruxit* by fallen trees, so boats could not pass.
examples.zh: 注释说河道被倒下的树木“阻塞了”（*obstruxit*），所以船只无法通过。

definition.en: (Rare in English writing) used as a learned/Latinized form related to English *obstruct* (“to block; to get in the way”).
definition.zh: （英语写作中较罕见）作为学术/拉丁化用法出现，与英语 *obstruct*（“阻挡；妨碍”）同源、意义相近。

examples.en: The editor glosses *obstruxit* as “obstructed,” to match modern English.
examples.zh: 编辑把 *obstruxit* 释义为“obstructed（被阻塞的）”，以对应现代英语表达。

extraExplanation: *obstruxit* 是拉丁语第三人称单数完成时，字面结构可理解为 ob-（表示“朝向/对着”）+ struere（“堆建、砌筑”），引申为“堆起来把路堵住”。
在英语里它通常只出现在引用拉丁原文的语境（例如古典文献、碑铭、校勘注释）中；日常英语更常用 *obstructed* 或 *blocked*。

summary.en: Obstupefy means to shock or amaze someone so much that they temporarily can’t think clearly.
summary.zh: Obstupefy 指“使人震惊到发懵”，一时难以反应或思考。

definition.en: to shock, amaze, or confuse someone so much that they cannot think clearly for a moment
definition.zh: 使震惊、目瞪口呆；使一时难以思考（因惊讶或困惑而脑子发懵）

examples.en: The sudden news seemed to obstupefy everyone in the room.
examples.zh: 这条突如其来的消息似乎让房间里所有人都目瞪口呆。

examples.en: I was obstupefied by how quickly the city changed in just a few years.
examples.zh: 我被这座城市短短几年内变化之快震住了。

extraExplanation: 词源上来自拉丁语，和 stupor（昏迷、麻木）同源，所以 obstupefy 的感觉更像“被震到发懵、短暂失语”，语气比 surprise 更强，也比 confuse 更偏向“震住了”的反应。
这个词比较书面、偏文学或正式表达；日常口语里更常说 be stunned / be amazed / be shocked。

summary.en: Obtain means to get something (often formally or through effort), or to achieve a result; in formal writing it can also mean “to exist/apply.”
summary.zh: Obtain 指（常较正式、通过努力或程序）获得/得到，也可指达成结果；在正式写作中还可表示“存在/适用”。

definition.en: to get something, especially by making an effort (for example, by searching, asking, or working for it)
definition.zh: （尤指通过努力，如寻找、请求或工作）获得、得到

examples.en: She obtained a visa after several weeks of paperwork.
examples.zh: 她办了好几周的手续后终于拿到了签证。

examples.en: You can obtain more information from the school office.
examples.zh: 你可以从学校办公室获得更多信息。

examples.en: He obtained permission to use the photo.
examples.zh: 他获得了使用那张照片的许可。

definition.en: to achieve or reach a particular result, level, or goal
definition.zh: 达成（结果/水平/目标）；取得（成就）

examples.en: The team obtained excellent results this season.
examples.zh: 这个队本赛季取得了很好的成绩。

examples.en: Students must obtain a passing grade to move on.
examples.zh: 学生必须取得及格成绩才能升级。

definition.en: (formal) to happen or be the case; to exist
definition.zh: （较正式）发生；适用；存在

examples.en: Different rules may obtain in different countries.
examples.zh: 不同国家可能适用不同的规则。

examples.en: Such conditions obtain only in rare cases.
examples.zh: 这种情况只在少数情况下存在。

extraExplanation: “obtain”语气比“get”更正式，常用于书面语、学术或官方场合（如 obtain a permit / obtain information）。
常见搭配：obtain permission/approval/consent（获得许可/批准/同意）；obtain a degree/qualification（获得学位/资格）；obtain data/evidence（获取数据/证据）。
词源：来自拉丁语 *obtinēre*，含有“抓住、持有、得到”的意思，因此常带有“通过努力或程序拿到”的感觉。

summary.en: “Obtainability” means how possible or easy it is to obtain something.
summary.zh: “obtainability”指“某物是否/多容易能被获得”的可获得性。

definition.en: The degree to which something can be obtained; how possible or easy it is to get something.
definition.zh: 可获得性；某物能够被获得的程度（得到的可能性或难易程度）。

examples.en: The drug’s obtainability depends on local laws and a doctor’s prescription.
examples.zh: 这种药的可获得性取决于当地法律以及医生处方。

examples.en: Improving internet access increased the obtainability of online education.
examples.zh: 改善网络接入提高了在线教育的可获得性。

extraExplanation: “obtainability”由动词 obtain（获得）+ 形容词后缀 -able（可以……的）+ 名词后缀 -ity（……性）构成，常见于较正式或学术语境。日常口语里更常说 availability（可用性/可获得性）或 how easy it is to get（有多容易得到）。

summary.en: “Obtainable” means “able to be obtained; available to get.”
summary.zh: “Obtainable”表示“可获得的、能拿到的”。

definition.en: Able to be gotten, bought, found, or achieved; available.
definition.zh: 可获得的；能得到的；可买到/可找到的；可实现的。

examples.en: Tickets are obtainable online and at the box office.
examples.zh: 票可以在网上和售票处买到。

examples.en: Clean water should be obtainable for everyone.
examples.zh: 每个人都应该能获得干净的水。

extraExplanation: 词形来源：obtainable = obtain（获得）+ -able（“能够……的”后缀）。常用于较正式的语境，比 available（可获得的）更强调“通过努力/手续等可以拿到”。
常见搭配：readily/easily obtainable（很容易获得的），not readily obtainable（不太容易获得的），obtainable resources/information（可获取的资源/信息）。

summary.en: Obtainableness means the degree to which something can be obtained or achieved.
summary.zh: Obtainableness 指某物“可获得/可实现”的程度。

definition.en: the quality of being obtainable; how possible or easy something is to get or achieve
definition.zh: 可获得性；可取得的程度（指某物有多可能或多容易得到/实现）

examples.en: The obtainableness of clean water varies greatly between regions.
examples.zh: 清洁用水的可获得性在不同地区差异很大。

examples.en: We discussed the obtainableness of the goal given our limited budget.
examples.zh: 在预算有限的情况下，我们讨论了这个目标的可实现性。

extraExplanation: “obtainableness”比较少见，更常用的表达是“availability（可用性/可获得性）”“accessibility（可达性/易获得性）”或“feasibility（可行性）”。
构词：obtain（获得）+ -able（可以…的）→ obtainable（可获得的）+ -ness（……性）→ obtainableness（可获得性）。在正式写作中偶尔会用来强调“能不能获得/多容易获得”这一点。

summary.en: “Obtainably” means “in a way that can be obtained,” but it is rare in everyday English.
summary.zh: “obtainably”表示“可获得地、可取得地”，但在日常英语中很少用。

definition.en: In a way that can be obtained; so that it is possible to get or achieve something.
definition.zh: 以可获得的方式；表示某物是可以得到或实现的。

examples.en: The medicine is legally obtainably only with a prescription.
examples.zh: 这种药在法律上只有凭处方才能获得。

examples.en: The information is obtainably through public records.
examples.zh: 这些信息可以通过公开记录获得。

extraExplanation: “obtainably”非常少见，多用于较正式的法律、学术或技术写作里。日常英语更常用的表达是“is obtainable / can be obtained / is available”。例如：The medicine is obtainable only with a prescription. / You can obtain the medicine only with a prescription.

summary.en: “Obtainal” is a nonstandard/rare word; in most contexts you should use “obtainable” meaning “able to be obtained.”
summary.zh: “obtainal”属于非标准/罕见用法；大多数语境应使用“obtainable”，意思是“可获得的”。

definition.en: Nonstandard or rare form; usually intended to mean “obtainable” (able to be obtained).
definition.zh: 非标准或罕见用法；通常是想表达“obtainable（可获得的）”。

examples.en: This form is not common in modern English; writers usually say “obtainable.”
examples.zh: 这种形式在现代英语里不常见；写作者通常用“obtainable”。

examples.en: Is this medicine obtainable without a prescription?
examples.zh: 这种药不用处方能买到吗？

extraExplanation: “obtainal”一般不被主流词典收录，常见情况是拼写错误或把“obtain”误加了“-al”。英语里表示“可……的”更常用“-able”，所以标准表达是“obtainable”。
如果你在学术或正式写作中看到“obtainal”，建议改为“obtainable”，或改写为“available/attainable”取决于语境。

summary.en: “Obtainance” is not standard English; use “obtaining” or “acquisition” instead.
summary.zh: “obtainance”不是标准英语；建议用“obtaining”或“acquisition”。

definition.en: A nonstandard or incorrect spelling of the noun forms related to “obtain.” In most contexts, use “obtaining” (the act of getting) or “acquisition” (the process/result of getting).
definition.zh: “obtain”的非标准/不正确名词形式。多数语境应使用“obtaining”（获得的行为/过程）或“acquisition”（获得的过程/结果）。

examples.en: The obtainance of a visa can take several weeks. (Better: The obtaining of a visa… / Visa acquisition…)
examples.zh: 获得签证可能需要几周。（更好：The obtaining of a visa… / Visa acquisition…）

examples.en: We discussed the obtainance of new equipment. (Better: obtaining new equipment / the acquisition of new equipment)
examples.zh: 我们讨论了获得新设备。（更好：obtaining new equipment / the acquisition of new equipment）

extraExplanation: “obtainance”在现代英语里几乎不被认可为标准词形，常见于拼写错误或少数非正式/非母语写作中。
如果你想表达“获得的过程/行为”，最自然的是“obtaining”。如果强调“获得到的东西”或更正式的“取得”，常用“acquisition”。
确实存在一个非常少见且偏正式的名词“obtainment”，意思接近“obtaining”，但日常写作里也不常用。

summary.en: “Obtained” means “got/acquired,” especially in a formal way.
summary.zh: “obtained”表示“得到/获得”，语气较正式。

definition.en: got something through effort, experience, or a process; acquired (often used with things like information, permission, results, or a degree).
definition.zh: 通过努力、经历或过程得到；获得（常用于信息、许可、结果、学位等）。

examples.en: She obtained permission to take photos in the museum.
examples.zh: 她获得了在博物馆拍照的许可。

examples.en: We obtained new information about the schedule.
examples.zh: 我们获得了关于日程安排的新信息。

definition.en: bought or received something; obtained (more formal than “got”).
definition.zh: 买到或收到某物；取得（比“got”更正式）。

examples.en: The books were obtained from a local store.
examples.zh: 这些书是从当地商店买到的。

examples.en: He obtained the documents from his lawyer.
examples.zh: 他从律师那里拿到了文件。

extraExplanation: “obtained”是动词“obtain”的过去式/过去分词。写作中常用来替换更口语的“got”，语气更正式。
常见搭配：obtain permission（获得许可）, obtain information/results/evidence（获得信息/结果/证据）, obtain a degree/certificate（获得学位/证书）。

summary.en: “Obtainer” means a person or organization that obtains something (formal and uncommon).
summary.zh: “Obtainer”指获得某物的人或机构（较正式且不常用）。

definition.en: A person who gets or acquires something, often by effort (a less common word; “obtainer” is usually replaced by “getter” or “recipient”).
definition.zh: 获得者；取得者（较不常用，常用“getter”或“recipient”来替代）。

examples.en: She was the obtainer of a scholarship after months of applications.
examples.zh: 她经过几个月的申请，最终成为奖学金的获得者。

examples.en: The company is the obtainer of a license to operate in the city.
examples.zh: 这家公司取得了在该市运营的许可。

extraExplanation: “obtainer”来自动词“obtain”（获得、取得）+ 表示人的后缀“-er”。在现代英语里它偏正式、偏书面，法律/行政文件中偶尔出现；日常对话更常说“get”或“receive”的相关表达。
近义词选择小提示：强调“努力争取到”可用“winner / achiever”；强调“被授予/收到”可用“recipient”；强调“拿到并占有”有时可用“acquirer”（更商业/法律语境）。

summary.en: “Obtainers” means people who obtain something (a formal/less common plural noun).
summary.zh: “obtainers”指“获得某物的人”，较正式且不太常用的复数名词。

definition.en: people who obtain something; people who succeed in getting, earning, or achieving something (plural of “obtainer”)
definition.zh: 获得者；取得某物/达成某事的人（“obtainer”的复数）

examples.en: Prize obtainers must show ID before collecting the award.
examples.zh: 领奖者在领取奖品前必须出示身份证件。

examples.en: The scholarship obtainers were announced on the school website.
examples.zh: 奖学金获得者已在学校官网公布。

extraExplanation: “obtainer”这个词在现代英语里不算常见；更自然的表达通常是 “people who obtain … / those who got …”，或用更具体的词，如 “winners（获胜者）”, “recipients（领取者/受领者）”, “achievers（达成者）”, “acquirers（获得者）”。
在法律、正式文件或较古风的语境中偶尔会看到 “obtainers”，用来强调“取得/获得”的行为本身，而不强调身份（例如“获奖者/受益人”那样的身份标签）。

summary.en: “Obtaining” means getting or acquiring something, often in a formal or effort-based way.
summary.zh: “obtaining”表示“获得/取得”，常用于较正式或强调通过努力、手续获得的语境。

definition.en: getting or acquiring something (the -ing form of “obtain”)
definition.zh: 获得；取得（动词 obtain 的 -ing 形式）

examples.en: She is obtaining a visa for her study program.
examples.zh: 她正在为留学项目办理签证。

examples.en: We are obtaining more information before making a decision.
examples.zh: 我们在做决定前正在获取更多信息。

examples.en: He succeeded in obtaining permission to leave early.
examples.zh: 他成功获得了提前离开的许可。

definition.en: achieving a result or reaching a goal (often used in formal writing)
definition.zh: 实现（结果）；达成（目标）（多用于较正式的表达）

examples.en: The team is obtaining better results this season.
examples.zh: 这支队本赛季取得了更好的成绩。

examples.en: By practicing daily, you are obtaining steady progress.
examples.zh: 通过每天练习，你在取得稳定的进步。

extraExplanation: “obtaining”常见于较正式/书面语（如申请、法律、学术语境）。口语里更常说“getting”。例如：getting a ticket（买/弄到票）比 obtaining a ticket 更自然。
“obtain”通常强调通过努力、过程或正式手续“获得”。因此在“obtaining a visa / permission / information”这类搭配中很常见。

summary.en: “Obtainment” means the act of obtaining something (formal; less common than “obtaining” or “acquisition”).
summary.zh: “Obtainment”指“获得/取得”的过程或行为（较正式，用得不如“obtaining / acquisition”常见）。

definition.en: The act or process of getting, achieving, or acquiring something; attainment.
definition.zh: 获得；取得；得到（某物的行为或过程）；达成。

examples.en: The obtainment of a visa can take several weeks.
examples.zh: 取得签证可能需要好几周。

examples.en: Her hard work led to the obtainment of a scholarship.
examples.zh: 她的努力让她获得了奖学金。

definition.en: Something that has been obtained; a result or gain (less common).
definition.zh: 获得的东西；成果；收获（较少用）。

examples.en: The report listed the project’s main obtainments.
examples.zh: 报告列出了该项目的主要成果。

extraExplanation: “Obtainment”在现代英语中偏正式、偏少见，日常更常用“obtaining / acquisition / attainment”。在法律、政策、学术写作中更可能见到，例如“the obtainment of consent（取得同意）”。
词根提示：obtain（获得）+ -ment（名词后缀，表示“行为/结果”），类似的还有“development, agreement”。

summary.en: Obtains means “gets” something (often formally), or (more formal) “exists/applies” in a situation.
summary.zh: Obtains 表示“获得/取得”（较正式），也可更正式地表示“适用/存在”。

definition.en: to get something, especially by effort, asking, or a planned process
definition.zh: 获得；取得（尤指通过努力、申请或有计划的过程）

examples.en: She obtains a visa before traveling.
examples.zh: 她在旅行前获得签证。

examples.en: The company obtains funding from investors.
examples.zh: 这家公司从投资者那里获得资金。

examples.en: He obtains permission to use the photo.
examples.zh: 他获得使用这张照片的许可。

definition.en: to exist or be true in a particular situation (formal)
definition.zh: （正式）适用；存在；成立（在某种情形下）

examples.en: Different rules obtain in this country.
examples.zh: 在这个国家，适用不同的规则。

examples.en: These conditions no longer obtain.
examples.zh: 这些情况已不再存在。

extraExplanation: “obtains”是动词“obtain”的第三人称单数：He/She/It obtains…；过去式/过去分词是 obtained。
“obtain”比“get”更正式，常见搭配有：obtain a visa/permit/permission/approval/information/evidence/funding。
“exist/be true”的用法多见于书面或法律/学术语境（如 rules obtain）。日常口语更常用 apply 或 be true。

summary.en: “Obtect” is a technical adjective meaning “covered over” or “not exposed,” often used in biology (e.g., obtect pupa).
summary.zh: “obtect”是一个偏专业的形容词，意思是“被覆盖的/不外露的”，常用于生物学描述（如 obtect pupa）。

definition.en: (technical, biology) Covered over; having a surface or parts hidden by an outer layer.
definition.zh: （专业用语，生物学）被覆盖的；外层包裹着、使表面或部分结构被遮住的。

examples.en: Many butterflies have an obtect pupa, where the legs and wings are tightly held against the body.
examples.zh: 许多蝴蝶的蛹属于“obtect”型：足和翅紧贴在身体上，被外层包裹。

examples.en: The description notes an obtect form, meaning the structures are not clearly exposed.
examples.zh: 描述中提到“obtect”形态，意思是这些结构并没有明显外露。

extraExplanation: “obtect”在日常英语里很少见，常见于昆虫学/动物学（如 obtect pupa，对比 exarate pupa：附肢外露、可自由活动）以及植物学等描述性文本。
它来自拉丁语词根 ob-（在……上/覆盖）+ tegere（覆盖），因此核心含义就是“被盖住、被包裹”。
如果你本来想写的是常用词“object”（/ˈɑːbdʒekt/ 名词“物体/对象”；/əbˈdʒekt/ 动词“反对”），拼写和读音都不同。

summary.en: “Objected” means “said no / disagreed,” often formally or strongly.
summary.zh: “Objected”表示“提出反对/不同意”，常带有正式或强烈反对的语气。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “object”: to express disagreement or say that you do not approve of something.
definition.zh: “object”的过去式/过去分词：表示反对、不同意或不赞成某事。

examples.en: Several students objected to the new rule.
examples.zh: 几名学生反对这条新规定。

examples.en: I objected because the plan felt unfair.
examples.zh: 我表示反对，因为这个计划让人觉得不公平。

examples.en: She objected when her name was used without permission.
examples.zh: 当她的名字未经允许被使用时，她提出了反对。

definition.en: In law or formal meetings, to officially raise an objection (for example, in court or during a discussion).
definition.zh: 在法律或正式会议中：正式提出异议（如在法庭或讨论中）。

examples.en: The defense objected to the question.
examples.zh: 辩方对这个问题提出异议。

examples.en: He objected during the meeting and asked for the decision to be delayed.
examples.zh: 他在会议中提出异议，并要求推迟决定。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“obtected”很可能是拼写错误，正确拼法是“objected”。
注意重音：动词 object（反对）重音在第二音节 /əbˈdʒɛkt/；名词 object（物体/对象）重音在第一音节 /ˈɑbdʒɛkt/。这在听力和口语里很关键。

summary.en: “Obtemper” means to obey or comply, usually in very formal or old-fashioned writing.
summary.zh: “obtemper”意为“服从、遵从”，多见于非常正式或较旧的书面语。

definition.en: to obey or comply with (a request, order, rule, or authority).
definition.zh: 服从；遵从（请求、命令、规则或权威）。

examples.en: Employees must obtemper the company’s safety rules.
examples.zh: 员工必须遵守公司的安全规定。

examples.en: He refused to obtemper the judge’s order.
examples.zh: 他拒绝服从法官的命令。

definition.en: to act in compliance; to follow instructions or authority (often followed by “with”).
definition.zh: 照做；遵命（常与 with 连用）。

examples.en: If you obtemper with these instructions, the process will go smoothly.
examples.zh: 如果你照这些说明去做，流程就会顺利。

examples.en: They did not obtemper with the new regulations.
examples.zh: 他们没有遵守新规。

extraExplanation: “obtemper”在现代英语中非常少见，语气偏正式、书面，常见于旧文献、法律或庄重文体。日常交流更常用 obey / comply (with) / follow。
词源上来自拉丁语，含义与“顺从（命令、权威）”紧密相关，因此搭配对象常是 order, command, rule, authority 等。

summary.en: “Obtemperate” means obedient or compliant.
summary.zh: “obtemperate”意为“顺从的、服从的”。

definition.en: Obedient; willing to follow orders, rules, or requests.
definition.zh: 顺从的；服从命令、规则或要求的。

examples.en: The obtemperate clerk followed the manager’s instructions without argument.
examples.zh: 那位顺从的职员毫无争辩地照经理的指示去做。

examples.en: In the story, the hero refuses to be obtemperate when the king demands blind loyalty.
examples.zh: 在故事里，国王要求盲目忠诚时，英雄拒绝再顺从。

extraExplanation: “obtemperate”较少见，语体偏正式/书面，多用于文学或较古典的表达。日常英语更常用 obedient、compliant、submissive。
词源上与拉丁语 *temperare*（调整、约束）相关，带有“按他人要求来约束自己、照办”的意味。

summary.en: “Obtend” is usually a misspelling of “obtain,” meaning to get or gain something.
summary.zh: “obtend” 通常是 “obtain” 的拼写错误，意思是“获得；得到”。

definition.en: to get or gain something (often by effort, request, or purchase)
definition.zh: 获得；得到（通常通过努力、申请或购买）

examples.en: She obtained a visa after submitting all the documents.
examples.zh: 她提交了所有材料后获得了签证。

examples.en: You can obtain more information on the school’s website.
examples.zh: 你可以在学校网站上获得更多信息。

examples.en: The team obtained permission to use the photos.
examples.zh: 团队获得了使用这些照片的许可。

extraExplanation: “obtend” 不是常见英语单词，通常是把 “obtain”（获得）拼错了。
“obtain” 在正式/书面语中更常见；日常口语里常用 “get”。例如：obtain information（获取信息）≈ get information（拿到/得到信息）。

summary.en: Obtenebrate means to obscure or darken something, literally or figuratively, and is mostly used in formal or literary contexts.
summary.zh: Obtenebrate 意为“使变暗/遮蔽、使变得不清晰”，既可指字面上的变暗，也可指比喻上的“使气氛或表达变得阴沉晦涩”，多见于正式或文学语境。

definition.en: (formal) To make something dark or less clear; to obscure.
definition.zh: （正式用语）使变暗；使不清晰；遮蔽。

examples.en: Thick fog obtenebrated the coastline, so the ships slowed down.
examples.zh: 浓雾遮蔽了海岸线，所以船只减速前行。

examples.en: Jargon can obtenebrate a simple idea instead of explaining it.
examples.zh: 行话可能会把简单的想法弄得更晦涩，而不是解释清楚。

definition.en: (literary) To darken (in mood or tone); to cast gloom over something.
definition.zh: （文学用语）使（氛围/语气）变得阴沉；给……蒙上阴影。

examples.en: The news of the accident obtenebrated the whole evening.
examples.zh: 事故的消息让整个夜晚都蒙上了阴影。

extraExplanation: 词源来自拉丁语：ob-（表示“覆盖/阻挡”）+ tenebrae（“黑暗”）。因此它的核心画面感是“用黑暗把某物盖住”。
这是非常少见且偏书面/文学的词。日常英语里更常用 obscure, darken, cloud, dim 来表达相近意思。
与常见词 tenebrous（“幽暗的；阴森的”）同源，tenebrae 也常出现在宗教或文学语境中表示“黑暗/阴影”。

summary.en: Obtenebration means ‘darkening/obscuring,’ literally or figuratively (clouding the mind).
summary.zh: obtenebration 指“变暗/遮蔽”，也可比喻“让思维或理解变得模糊”。

definition.en: the act or process of making something dark or hard to see; obscuration
definition.zh: 使变暗、遮蔽；变暗的过程（遮暗）

examples.en: Smoke caused the obtenebration of the skyline.
examples.zh: 烟雾使天际线变得昏暗难辨。

examples.en: Heavy curtains created a gentle obtenebration in the room.
examples.zh: 厚窗帘让房间里出现一种柔和的昏暗。

definition.en: (figurative) the clouding of the mind or understanding; mental or moral obscurity
definition.zh: （比喻）思维或理解变得模糊；精神/道德上的蒙昧

examples.en: Grief can bring an obtenebration of judgment.
examples.zh: 悲痛可能会让判断力变得模糊。

examples.en: The novel describes the character’s slow obtenebration as paranoia grows.
examples.zh: 小说描写了人物在偏执加深时逐渐陷入精神蒙昧的过程。

extraExplanation: 这是一个很书面、偏文学的词，日常英语里更常用 **darkening / dimming / obscuration**（变暗、遮蔽）或 **confusion / clouding**（思维变得混乱/模糊）。
词源来自拉丁语：**ob-**（向着、加强）+ **tenebrae**（黑暗）。因此它带有“把光遮住、让事物陷入黑暗”的画面感，常用于描写氛围或心理状态。

summary.en: Obtain means to get or achieve something, usually in a formal or effortful way.
summary.zh: obtain 表示“获得、取得或达成”，通常语气较正式，强调通过努力或程序得到。

definition.en: to get something, especially by making an effort or through a process (requesting, buying, earning, etc.)
definition.zh: 获得；取得（尤指通过努力或某个过程，如申请、购买、赚取等）

examples.en: She obtained a visa after several weeks of paperwork.
examples.zh: 她办理了好几周的手续后终于拿到了签证。

examples.en: You can obtain information from the official website.
examples.zh: 你可以从官方网站获取信息。

definition.en: to succeed in reaching an agreement, result, or position
definition.zh: 达成（协议/结果）；获得（职位/资格）

examples.en: The two sides finally obtained an agreement.
examples.zh: 双方最终达成了协议。

examples.en: He obtained a leadership role in the club.
examples.zh: 他在社团里获得了领导职位。

extraExplanation: “obtenere”常见于拉丁语动词“obtinēre”（也写作 obtinere），意思是“握住、坚持、获得”，是英语 obtain 的词源之一。
英语里更常用的是 obtain（较正式），日常口语中常用 get。比如：obtain permission ≈ get permission（获得许可）。

summary.en: “Obtenir” is a French verb meaning “to obtain/get,” often used in a more formal sense like securing permission, an agreement, or a result.
summary.zh: “obtenir”是法语动词，意思是“获得/取得”，常较正式，用于指争取到许可、协议或某种结果。

definition.en: (French verb) To obtain; to get or achieve something you want through effort, request, or decision.
definition.zh: （法语动词）获得；取得；通过努力、请求或决定而得到想要的东西。

examples.en: She managed to obtain a visa after several weeks of paperwork.
examples.zh: 她在准备了好几周材料后终于拿到了签证。

examples.en: In French you can say: Il a obtenu un emploi. (He got a job.)
examples.zh: 法语里可以说：Il a obtenu un emploi.（他找到了一份工作。）

definition.en: (French, more formal) To secure something officially, such as permission, an agreement, or a result.
definition.zh: （法语，较正式）正式获批/争取到（许可、协议、结果等）。

examples.en: They obtained permission to publish the photos.
examples.zh: 他们获得了发布这些照片的许可。

examples.en: In French: Elle a obtenu l’accord du directeur.
examples.zh: 法语：Elle a obtenu l’accord du directeur.（她得到了校长/主管的同意。）

extraExplanation: “obtenir”是法语不定式，常见搭配有：obtenir quelque chose（获得某物）；obtenir quelque chose de quelqu’un（从某人那里得到某物）；obtenir que + 从句（设法让……发生）。语气通常比英语的“get”更正式，更接近“obtain/secure”。

summary.en: “Obtent” is a rare word meaning “obtained,” and in Scottish legal English it can mean an obtained court judgment.
summary.zh: “obtent”很少见，意为“获得的”；在苏格兰法律英语中也可指“已取得的法院判决/裁定”。

definition.en: (rare/archaic) obtained; gained or secured.
definition.zh: （罕见/古用）获得的；取得的；争取到的。

examples.en: He spoke of the honors obtent through years of service.
examples.zh: 他谈起多年服务所获得的荣誉。

examples.en: The benefits are not automatic—they must be sought and obtent.
examples.zh: 这些好处不是自动得到的——必须去争取并获得。

definition.en: (law, chiefly Scottish English) a judgment, decree, or other legal decision that has been obtained (from a court).
definition.zh: （法律，多见于苏格兰英语）已取得的判决/裁定；（从法院）获得的法律决定。

examples.en: The creditor enforced an obtent against the debtor’s property.
examples.zh: 债权人依据已取得的判决对债务人的财产进行执行。

examples.en: They relied on an earlier obtent to support their claim.
examples.zh: 他们依赖先前获得的判决来支持自己的主张。

extraExplanation: “obtent”在现代日常英语中非常少见；一般表达“获得的”会用更常见的 obtained / gained / secured。
在法律语境里（尤其苏格兰法律英语），obtent 常指“已经拿到的判决/裁定”，属于专业用语；在普通写作中不建议使用，除非你确实在写法律或历史材料。
词源上与 obtain 同源，来自拉丁语 obtinēre（意为“取得、获得”）。

summary.en: “Obtention” means the act or process of obtaining something, used mainly in formal contexts and less common than “obtaining” or “acquisition.”
summary.zh: “obtention”意为“获得、取得”的行为或过程，主要用于较正式语境，比“obtaining / acquisition”少见。

definition.en: the act or process of obtaining something; the fact of having obtained it (formal, less common)
definition.zh: 获得；取得（某物）的行为或过程；获得的结果（正式用语，较不常见）

examples.en: The policy outlines the steps for the obtention of a visa.
examples.zh: 该政策概述了取得签证的步骤。

examples.en: They discussed the obtention of funding for the new project.
examples.zh: 他们讨论了为新项目获得资金的事。

examples.en: Document obtention may take several weeks.
examples.zh: 文件的取得可能需要数周时间。

extraExplanation: “obtention”在现代英语里较少见，更常用的是“obtaining / acquisition / getting”，有时也会看到“obtainment”。在法律、行政或非常正式的写作中偶尔出现。
常见搭配：the obtention of + 名词（如：the obtention of permission / documents / a visa）。
注意拼写与“obstruction（阻碍）”“obligation（义务）”不同，发音重音在第二音节：ob-TEN-tion。

summary.en: “obtest” isn’t a recognized English word; it’s likely a typo or a test string.
summary.zh: “obtest”不是规范英语词汇；很可能是拼写错误或测试字符串。

definition.en: Not a standard English word. It may be a typo or a made-up/test string.
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词。可能是拼写错误或用于测试的字符串。

examples.en: I couldn’t find “obtest” in a dictionary—did you mean “object” or “obtest” as a test word?
examples.zh: 我在词典里找不到“obtest”——你是想写“object”，还是把“obtest”当作测试词？

extraExplanation:
“obtest”在常见英语词典中没有收录，也不属于常见缩写。最可能是：
1）把“object（物体/对象；反对）”打错了；
2）想写“obtuse（迟钝的；钝角的）”或“ob-test（某种内部标记/测试用写法）”；
3）单纯用于测试输入。
如果你告诉我它出现的句子或上下文（例如软件界面、论文、聊天内容），我可以更准确判断你想表达的词。

summary.en: Obtestation means an earnest, often formal plea or a solemn appeal (sometimes to a higher power).
summary.zh: obtestation 指恳切而较正式的请求/呼吁；也可指庄重地向神明或他人作证的呼告。

definition.en: an earnest request or plea; a strong appeal (often formal or old-fashioned).
definition.zh: 恳切的请求；强烈的呼吁（常较正式或带古风）。

examples.en: Despite her obtestation, he refused to change his mind.
examples.zh: 尽管她再三恳求，他还是拒绝改变主意。

examples.en: The letter ends with an obtestation for peace.
examples.zh: 这封信以对和平的强烈呼吁作结。

definition.en: a solemn appeal to a higher power or to someone as a witness (often in religious or formal language).
definition.zh: 郑重地诉诸神明或请某人作证的呼告（常见于宗教或庄重语境）。

examples.en: In the old text, the speaker makes an obtestation to heaven.
examples.zh: 在那篇古旧文本中，说话者郑重地向上天呼告。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较少见，带有书面语/古典气息；在现代英语里更常用的替代词是 plea, earnest request, appeal。
词源上与拉丁语的“作证、呼告”有关，因此第二个义项常带“请……作证/向神明呼告”的庄重色彩。

summary.en: “Obtested” is the past form of “obtest,” an archaic formal verb meaning to beg earnestly or to call upon as a witness.
summary.zh: “obtested”是“obtest”的过去式，属于较古旧的正式用法，意思是“郑重恳求”或“援引……作证”。

definition.en: (Archaic, formal) to beg or urge someone very strongly and seriously; to appeal to someone earnestly.
definition.zh: （古语/正式）恳求；郑重地请求（某人）

examples.en: She obtested him to forgive her and start again.
examples.zh: 她郑重地恳求他原谅自己并重新开始。

examples.en: I obtest you to tell the truth.
examples.zh: 我郑重地请求你说出真相。

definition.en: (Archaic) to call on someone or something as a witness; to appeal to as proof.
definition.zh: （古语）援引……为证；请……作证

examples.en: He obtested heaven as witness to his innocence.
examples.zh: 他援引上天作证，证明自己清白。

examples.en: The poet obtested history to remember the fallen.
examples.zh: 诗人请求历史铭记逝者。

extraExplanation: “obtested”是动词“obtest”的过去式/过去分词。这个词在现代英语里很少见，多出现在宗教文字、古典文学或模仿古风的写作中。
词源来自拉丁语 *obtestari*（郑重恳求、呼唤作证），因此常带有“庄严、郑重、带誓言感”的语气。现代更常用的替代说法有：*beg*, *urge*, *implore*, *adjure*（更正式）。

summary.en: A/B testing compares two versions (A and B) to learn which one performs better with real users.
summary.zh: A/B测试是用真实用户对比两个版本（A与B），看哪个表现更好。

definition.en: A method of comparing two versions (A and B) of something—such as a webpage, app screen, email, or ad—to see which performs better based on real user data.
definition.zh: 一种对比两个版本（A版与B版）的测试方法，例如网页、App界面、邮件或广告，用真实用户数据来判断哪个表现更好。

examples.en: We ran A/B testing on the landing page to improve sign-ups.
examples.zh: 我们对落地页做了A/B测试来提升注册量。

examples.en: In A/B testing, only one element changed—like the button color—so we could measure its impact.
examples.zh: 在A/B测试中我们只改动一个元素（比如按钮颜色），这样才能衡量它的影响。

extraExplanation: “A/B testing”常见于产品、增长、市场营销与数据分析领域，也常写作“AB testing”。核心思路是把用户随机分成两组（或多组），分别看到不同版本，再用点击率、转化率等指标比较效果。
为了让结果更可靠，通常需要：随机分流、样本量足够、一次只改一个关键变量、并运行到足够时间（避免只看短期波动）。
它与更广义的“experiment / controlled experiment（对照实验）”概念接近；当版本不止两个时也会说“multivariate testing（多变量测试）”或“split testing（分流测试）”。

summary.en: “obtests” isn’t a recognized English word; it’s likely a typo (e.g., “objects,” “tests,” or “OB tests” in a medical context).
summary.zh: “obtests”不是公认的英文单词；很可能是拼写错误（如“objects”“tests”，或医学语境中的“OB tests”）。

definition.en: Not a standard English word; most likely a typo or misspelling.
definition.zh: 不是标准英文单词；很可能是拼写错误或误打。

examples.en: I can’t find “obtests” in a dictionary—did you mean “objects” or “tests”?
examples.zh: 我在词典里找不到“obtests”——你是不是想写“objects（物体/对象）”或“tests（测试）”？‍

extraExplanation:
“obtests”在常见英语词典与语料中几乎不出现，因此更像是误拼。最接近、也最常见的可能是：
1) objects /ˈɑbdʒekts/（名词复数“物体/对象”，或动词第三人称“反对”）；
2) ob tests（在医疗或生物学语境里，OB 可能指 obstetrics 产科；“OB tests”=产科检查/筛查）。
如果你能提供句子或上下文（例如一整句、学科领域），我可以帮你确定正确词并解释用法。

summary.en: Obtrect is an archaic verb meaning to slander or defame someone.
summary.zh: obtrect 是个古语动词，意思是“诽谤、诋毁（损害名誉）”。

definition.en: (Archaic) To speak against someone; to slander or defame.
definition.zh: （古语）诽谤、诋毁；说某人的坏话以损害其名誉。

examples.en: In the pamphlet, he tried to obtrect his political rivals with false claims.
examples.zh: 在那本小册子里，他用不实指控来诽谤自己的政敌。

examples.en: She refused to obtrect her former friend, even after the argument.
examples.zh: 即使争吵过后，她也拒绝诋毁曾经的朋友。

extraExplanation: 这是一个非常少见的古语/书面词，现代英语里几乎不用。日常表达更常用 slander（口头/法律语境的“诽谤”）、defame（正式/法律“损害名誉”）、badmouth（口语“说坏话”）。
词源来自拉丁语 obtrectare，含有“贬低、诋毁”的意思；因此常见于较早期的宗教、政治争论或论战文本中。

summary.en: Obtriangular means shaped like a triangle with an obtuse angle, often used in geometry and botany.
summary.zh: obtriangular 指“钝角三角形状的”，常见于几何与植物学形态描述中。

definition.en: (of a shape) having the form of a triangle with one obtuse angle; shaped like an “obtriangular” triangle (broad at the top, narrower at the base).
definition.zh: （形状）呈“钝角三角形”的；具有一个钝角的三角形外形（上端较宽、下端较窄）。

examples.en: The diagram shows an obtriangular triangle with one angle greater than 90 degrees.
examples.zh: 这张图示展示了一个钝角三角形，其中一个角大于90度。

examples.en: In botany, some leaves are described as obtriangular when they look like an inverted, obtuse-angled triangle.
examples.zh: 在植物学中，有些叶片会被描述为“钝角三角形状”（obtriangular），因为它们看起来像倒置的钝角三角形。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较少见，多出现在几何学和植物形态学的描述中。它由 ob-（常表示“倒置/相反方向”）+ triangular（“三角形的”）构成，常用来强调“像倒过来的三角形”，且带有钝角。
在植物学里，obtriangular 往往用来描述叶片或器官“上部更宽、基部更窄”的轮廓；如果你看到相近词 obovate（倒卵形）、obcordate（倒心形），它们的 ob- 也是类似用法。

summary.en: Obtrude means to push yourself or something into a place or situation where it isn’t wanted, or to stand out in an unpleasant way.
summary.zh: Obtrude 指在不受欢迎时强行介入/打扰，或以令人不快的方式显得突兀。

definition.en: to push or force yourself, your opinions, or your presence into a situation where you are not wanted
definition.zh: （在不受欢迎时）硬挤进去；强行介入；把自己/观点强加于人

examples.en: I didn’t want to obtrude on their private conversation, so I waited outside.
examples.zh: 我不想打扰他们的私人谈话，所以我在外面等。

examples.en: He tends to obtrude his political opinions at family dinners.
examples.zh: 他常常在家庭晚餐时把自己的政治观点强加给别人。

examples.en: Please don’t obtrude your help unless someone asks for it.
examples.zh: 除非有人开口求助，否则请不要硬要帮忙。

definition.en: to stick out or be noticeable in an unpleasant or unwelcome way
definition.zh: （以令人不快的方式）突兀地显眼；刺眼地冒出来

examples.en: A bright logo obtruded on the simple design.
examples.zh: 一个醒目的标志在简洁的设计上显得很突兀。

examples.en: The microphone obtruded into the edge of the photo.
examples.zh: 麦克风出现在照片边缘，显得很碍眼。

extraExplanation: “obtrude”常带有“打扰、冒犯、越界”的语气，比“appear/show”更负面。常见搭配：obtrude on/upon (someone/something)（打扰/侵扰），obtrude oneself（不请自来、硬凑上去），obtrude one’s opinions (on others)（把观点强加于人）。
词源上与“trude=push（推）”有关（同源词：intrude 侵扰，protrude 突出，extrude 挤出）。记忆法：ob-（朝向/对着）+ trude（推）→“硬推到别人面前”。

summary.en: “Obtruded” means something pushed itself into notice or someone forced themselves/ideas into a situation (often unwanted).
summary.zh: “obtruded”表示（不受欢迎地）闯入注意范围或硬插入场合/把想法强加给别人。

definition.en: past tense / past participle of “obtrude”: to push itself forward into notice, or to force itself into a situation or conversation in an unwanted way.
definition.zh: “obtrude”的过去式/过去分词：指（某物/某人）闯入视线或注意范围；或不受欢迎地插入、打扰（某个场合/谈话）。

examples.en: A painful memory obtruded while I was trying to work.
examples.zh: 我正想专心工作时，一段痛苦的回忆突然闯入脑海。

examples.en: He obtruded into the conversation and changed the topic.
examples.zh: 他硬插进谈话里，把话题给带偏了。

examples.en: Their opinions were obtruded on everyone at the meeting.
examples.zh: 在会上，他们把自己的观点强加给了所有人。

definition.en: to stick out or protrude; to project outward.
definition.zh: （较少用）突出、伸出；凸出。

examples.en: A thin branch obtruded through the broken window.
examples.zh: 一根细树枝从破窗户里伸了进来。

extraExplanation: “obtruded”常见搭配是 obtrude on/upon someone（把……强加给某人）和 obtrude into something（硬插入某事/某场合）。语气偏正式，常带负面评价，强调“多余、打扰、不受欢迎”。
和 “intrude” 很像：intrude 更强调“闯入/打扰（未经允许）”；obtrude 更强调“把自己或某事推到别人面前”，让人不得不注意到。

summary.en: An obtruder is someone who comes into a place or situation uninvited or unwanted.
summary.zh: obtruder 指未经邀请或不受欢迎地进入某处或某种场合的人。

definition.en: a person who enters a place or situation where they are not wanted, invited, or allowed
definition.zh: 闯入者；擅自进入（不受欢迎或未经允许的）人

examples.en: The obtruder ran away when the security guard shouted.
examples.zh: 保安一喊，闯入者就跑了。

examples.en: She felt like an obtruder at the private meeting and left quietly.
examples.zh: 她觉得自己像个不速之客，于是悄悄离开了。

extraExplanation: “obtruder”来自动词“obtrude”（硬闯、强行进入；把自己或观点强加于人）。因此它不只用于“非法闯入”，也常用于社交场合，表示“打扰、不合时宜地出现的人”。
近义词里：intruder更常见、更中性；obtruder更强调“硬凑上来/不合时宜地介入”的感觉。

summary.en: “Obtruders” means people who intrude—enter or interfere where they are not welcome.
summary.zh: “obtruders”指闯入或插手他人事务、在不受欢迎的情况下进入/打扰的人（复数）。

definition.en: people who enter a place, situation, or conversation where they are not wanted; intruders
definition.zh: 闯入者；擅自进入者；不受欢迎的打扰者

examples.en: The security guard asked the obtruders to leave the building immediately.
examples.zh: 保安要求那些闯入者立刻离开大楼。

examples.en: We were having a private talk, but two obtruders kept interrupting us.
examples.zh: 我们正在私下交谈，但有两个人一直闯进来打断我们。

examples.en: The hikers felt uneasy when they saw obtruders near their campsite at night.
examples.zh: 夜里看到营地附近有闯入者，徒步者感到不安。

extraExplanation: “obtruders”是“obtruder（闯入者）”的复数形式，来自动词“obtrude/ intrude（硬闯、打扰）”。在日常英语里，更常用的词是“intruders（闯入者）”；“obtruder(s)”较少见，语气往往更强调“冒犯、强行打扰”。

summary.en: “Obtrudes” means to push into someone’s space or attention in an unwelcome way, or to stick out noticeably.
summary.zh: “obtrudes”指（令人不快地）硬闯入他人空间/注意力，或指物体显眼地凸出。

definition.en: (of a person or thing) to force itself into a place, situation, or someone’s attention in a way that is unwanted.
definition.zh: （人或事物）硬插进某个场合或进入他人注意范围，令人不快或不受欢迎。

examples.en: He obtrudes on private conversations and makes people uncomfortable.
examples.zh: 他总爱插入别人的私下谈话，让人很不舒服。

examples.en: Bright ads obtrude on the reading experience.
examples.zh: 刺眼的广告打扰了阅读体验。

definition.en: to stick out; to project outward in a noticeable way.
definition.zh: 突出；凸出（显眼地伸出）。

examples.en: A small bone obtrudes slightly near his ankle.
examples.zh: 他脚踝附近有一块小骨头微微凸出。

examples.en: The rock obtrudes from the surface of the water.
examples.zh: 那块岩石从水面突了出来。

extraExplanation: “obtrudes”是动词“obtrude”的第三人称单数（he/she/it obtrudes）。语气通常偏负面，常和介词 on/upon 连用：obtrude on/upon someone（打扰、唐突闯入）。
与“intrude”相近，但“obtrude”更强调“让自己/某物变得显眼、强行进入注意力”，可用于人、话题、广告、想法等。

summary.en: “Obtruding” means sticking out noticeably or (of a person/idea) pushing into attention in an unwanted way.
summary.zh: “obtruding”指（物体）显眼地突出，或（人/想法）不受欢迎地闯入、硬要引人注意。

definition.en: sticking out; projecting in a way that is noticeable (often unpleasant or unwanted).
definition.zh: （物体）突出的；伸出的；（常指）显眼得让人不舒服或不合时宜的。

examples.en: A loose wire was obtruding from the wall.
examples.zh: 一根松动的电线从墙里突出来。

examples.en: He tried to hide the obtruding tag on his shirt.
examples.zh: 他试着把衬衫上露出来的标签藏起来。

definition.en: present participle of “obtrude”: to stick out, or to force something (or yourself) into notice or attention when it is not wanted.
definition.zh: “obtrude”的现在分词：指（自己或事物）突出来；或（尤指想法、问题、人）不受欢迎地闯入、硬要引人注意。

examples.en: A few nails were obtruding from the old fence.
examples.zh: 几颗钉子从旧篱笆上突出来。

examples.en: She apologized for obtruding on their private conversation.
examples.zh: 她为打扰他们的私下谈话而道歉。

examples.en: His personal opinions kept obtruding into the report.
examples.zh: 他的个人观点不断硬塞进那份报告里。

extraExplanation: “obtruding/obtrude”常带有“多余、碍眼、令人不适”的语气；比起中性描述的“stick out”，它更强调“突兀、打扰”。
词源来自拉丁语 ob-（向前/对着）+ trudere（推），原义有“推到前面去、硬塞到别人面前”的感觉，因此也常用于抽象事物（问题、观点、回忆）“不合时宜地冒出来”。
与“intrude”相比：intrude更常指“人闯入/打扰”；obtrude既可指人，也常指“事物或想法”突兀地显露或被强行提出。

summary.en: Obtruncate is a rare word meaning “blunt or cut off at the tip,” especially in botanical descriptions; it can also mean “to blunt by cutting off the end.”
summary.zh: obtruncate 是个罕见词，主要指“末端被截平、呈钝状”，常见于植物学描述；也可作动词表示“截去末端使其变钝”。

definition.en: (Rare) having a blunt or squared-off end; cut off at the tip.
definition.zh: （罕见）末端钝的；顶端被截平的。

examples.en: The leaf is obtruncate, ending in a small flat tip rather than a point.
examples.zh: 这片叶子是钝截形的，末端是小小的平面，而不是尖端。

examples.en: In botanical descriptions, “obtruncate” contrasts with “acute” (pointed).
examples.zh: 在植物学描述中，“obtruncate（钝截形）”与“acute（尖形）”相对。

definition.en: (Rare, transitive) to make something blunt by cutting off the end; to truncate.
definition.zh: （罕见，及物）把……末端截去使其变钝；截短。

examples.en: The craftsman obtruncated the rod so it would not scratch the surface.
examples.zh: 工匠把杆的末端截平，使它不至于刮伤表面。

extraExplanation: “obtruncate”非常少见，更多时候你会看到更常用的词“truncate（截短）”或形容词“truncated（被截短的）”。在植物学里，它常用来描述叶片、花瓣等的“顶端形状”。
词形提示：前缀“ob-”在一些形容词里可表示“朝向……/相对”的感觉；这里可理解为“端部呈截断状”。

summary.en: Obtruncation means cutting off or shortening something by removing an end; in older usage it may also mean beheading.
summary.zh: Obtruncation 指“截断/截短”，把末端砍掉使其变短；在较旧用法中也可指“斩首”。

definition.en: the act of cutting something off; shortening by removing an end (sometimes used for beheading or cutting off a head in older texts).
definition.zh: 截断；砍掉末端使之变短（在较旧的文本中有时也指“砍头/斩首”）。

examples.en: The editor’s heavy obtruncation of the article removed the final explanation.
examples.zh: 编辑对文章进行了大幅截断，把最后的解释删掉了。

examples.en: In some historical writings, obtruncation can refer to beheading as a form of execution.
examples.zh: 在一些历史写作中，obtruncation 也可指作为处刑方式的斩首。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较少见，常见替代词是 truncation（截短/删节）或 cutting off（切除/截去）。
词源来自拉丁语：ob-（表示“朝向、对着”或加强语气）+ truncare（砍断、截断）。因此它带有“砍掉一截”的强烈画面感。
在学术或技术语境（如数据处理、统计、排版）里通常用 truncation；obtruncation 更可能出现在文学化、古旧或强调“砍断/斩首”意象的表达中。

summary.en: A very rare noun meaning a cutter or device that truncates (cuts something short). Often confused with “obturator.”
summary.zh: 一个非常罕见的名词，指“截断/切除的工具或装置”。在医学语境中常与“obturator（闭孔相关）”混淆。

definition.en: (Rare) Something that truncates or cuts off a part; a cutter or trimming device.
definition.zh: （罕见）用来截断、切除一部分的东西；切割器、修剪装置。

examples.en: The report mentions an old surgical obtruncator used to remove damaged tissue.
examples.zh: 报告提到一种旧式外科“obtruncator”，用于切除受损组织。

examples.en: In this context, “obtruncator” is basically a tool that cuts something short.
examples.zh: 在这里，“obtruncator”基本就是把东西“截短”的工具。

extraExplanation: 这个词在现代英语中非常少见，很多情况下可能是拼写或识别错误。常见的医学/解剖学相关词是 **obturator**（如 obturator nerve/foramen，闭孔神经/闭孔）。如果你是在解剖或医学文本里看到它，建议核对原文是否其实是 *obturator*。
词形上看，它像是由 *truncate*（截短）相关的 *truncator*（截断者/截断器）加上前缀 *ob-* 形成，但在主流词典与常用语料里出现率很低。

summary.en: Obtrusion means an unwelcome intrusion into someone’s space or conversation, or a physical projection that sticks out.
summary.zh: Obtrusion 指对他人空间/谈话的不受欢迎的打扰，也可指物体的突出或凸出物。

definition.en: an act of pushing in or forcing something into a place where it is not wanted; an unwelcome intrusion
definition.zh: （不受欢迎的）闯入；侵扰；强行插入

examples.en: I apologized for my obtrusion and left them to talk in private.
examples.zh: 我为自己的打扰道歉，然后让他们私下谈话。

examples.en: Please excuse my obtrusion, but I need to ask you a quick question.
examples.zh: 请原谅我冒昧打扰一下，我需要问你一个简短的问题。

definition.en: the state of sticking out or projecting; something that protrudes
definition.zh: 突出；凸出物

examples.en: A small obtrusion on the wall showed where a pipe ran behind it.
examples.zh: 墙上一处小小的凸起显示出后面有管道经过。

examples.en: The dentist smoothed the obtrusion so it wouldn’t rub against my tongue.
examples.zh: 牙医把那处凸起磨平，免得磨到我的舌头。

extraExplanation: 词源上与 obtrude（强行闯入／突出）同源：ob-（向前、对着）+ trudere（推）。因此它既可指“打扰别人”，也可指“物体突出来”。
在日常英语里，形容人或行为“很打扰、很碍眼”更常用 intrusive / intrusion；obtrusion 相对更正式，常见于书面语或技术语境（如牙科、工程描述“凸出”）。

summary.en: An obtrusionist is someone who intrudes on others in an unwelcome way.
summary.zh: obtrusionist 指不受欢迎地打扰或越界介入他人的人。

definition.en: a person who pushes themselves into other people’s space, attention, or conversations in an unwelcome way; an intrusive person
definition.zh: （不受欢迎地）硬挤进他人空间/注意力/谈话的人；爱打扰、爱插手的人

examples.en: He’s an obtrusionist who keeps joining private conversations without being invited.
examples.zh: 他是个爱硬插进来的家伙，总是不请自来地加入别人的私密谈话。

examples.en: The meeting went badly because an obtrusionist kept interrupting everyone.
examples.zh: 会议进行得很糟，因为有个人一直插话打断所有人。

extraExplanation: “Obtrusionist”并不常见，更常用的表达是 intrusive person / busybody / meddler。它来自 obtrude（硬闯、唐突介入）→ obtrusion（闯入、打扰）→ obtrusionist（做这种事的人）。
语气通常带批评或不满，表示对方“越界、没分寸”。在正式写作中，也可用 more tactful（更委婉）的说法：overly involved / overly familiar（过分介入/过分熟络）。

summary.en: Obtrusions are unwelcome interruptions or projecting parts that stick out.
summary.zh: Obtrusions 指不受欢迎的打扰，或（科技语境中）突出的凸起部分。

definition.en: (plural of obtrusion) an unwelcome interruption or something that pushes into a place or situation where it is not wanted.
definition.zh: （obtrusion 的复数）不受欢迎的打扰；（不该出现却）硬插进来的事物/行为。

examples.en: I tried to work, but the constant obtrusions made it hard to concentrate.
examples.zh: 我想工作，但不断的打扰让我很难集中注意力。

examples.en: Please excuse my obtrusions—I didn’t realize you were in a meeting.
examples.zh: 请原谅我的打扰——我没意识到你在开会。

definition.en: a part that sticks out or projects from something (especially in science or technical contexts).
definition.zh: （尤用于科技语境）突出的部分；凸起物。

examples.en: The doctor examined the small obtrusions along the bone in the X-ray.
examples.zh: 医生查看了 X 光片中骨头上的小凸起。

examples.en: Engineers removed the obtrusions to make the surface smooth.
examples.zh: 工程师去除了凸起部分，使表面更平滑。

extraExplanation: “obtrusion”来自拉丁语词根：ob-（朝向/对着）+ trudere（推）。所以它的核心画面是“把东西推到别人面前”，常带有“打扰、冒犯”的负面语气。
在文学或正式写作里，obtrusion 常用来形容“让人不舒服的打断”或“硬插入的存在”，比 interruption 更强调“不受欢迎/不得体”。

summary.en: “Obtrusive” describes something that stands out too much and feels annoying or intrusive.
summary.zh: “obtrusive”形容某事物过于显眼或冒犯性地引人注意，让人觉得被打扰或不舒服。

definition.en: Too noticeable in a way that is annoying or unwanted; attracting attention when it should not.
definition.zh: （因不合时宜而）过于显眼的；突兀的；碍眼的；惹人烦的。

examples.en: The bright ad banner on the website was really obtrusive.
examples.zh: 网站上那个亮眼的广告横幅非常碍眼。

examples.en: He apologized for being obtrusive and stopped asking personal questions.
examples.zh: 他为自己唐突而道歉，并停止追问私人问题。

examples.en: They chose soft colors so the sign wouldn’t look obtrusive.
examples.zh: 他们选了柔和的颜色，这样牌子看起来就不会太突兀。

extraExplanation: 词源上来自拉丁语 ob-（“朝向/对着”）+ trudere（“推”），本义有“硬挤进去、强行冒出来”的感觉，所以常带有“打扰、令人不舒服”的语气。
常见搭配：obtrusive behavior（唐突的行为）、obtrusive question（冒昧的问题）、obtrusive advertising（扰人的广告）、obtrusive noise（刺耳/烦人的噪声）。
近义词区别：noticeable 只是“显眼/明显”（可中性），prominent 是“突出/重要”（多为中性或褒义），obtrusive 则强调“显眼到让人不舒服”。

summary.en: “Obtrusively” means in an overly noticeable, pushy, often annoying way.
summary.zh: “obtrusively”表示“过分显眼、强行引人注意（常令人不适/厌烦）地”。

definition.en: in a way that is too noticeable or pushes itself into someone’s attention; in an annoying or inappropriate way
definition.zh: 以过分显眼、强行闯入他人注意的方式；（常指）唐突地、惹人烦地

examples.en: A large microphone stood obtrusively in the middle of the table.
examples.zh: 一个大麦克风很突兀地立在桌子中央。

examples.en: He obtrusively interrupted the conversation to talk about himself.
examples.zh: 他唐突地打断谈话，把话题扯到自己身上。

examples.en: The logo was placed obtrusively on the front of the shirt.
examples.zh: 商标被很碍眼地印在衬衫正面。

extraExplanation: “obtrusively”来自形容词“obtrusive”（突兀的、碍眼的），常用于描述物品的摆放/设计（如广告、标志、噪音、装饰）或人的行为（插话、打扰），语气通常带负面评价。
同类表达：noticeably（只是“明显”，不一定令人反感）、intrusively（更强调“侵扰/侵犯私人空间或隐私”）。

summary.en: Obtrusiveness is the quality of being unpleasantly noticeable or pushy—either in behavior (too interfering) or in appearance (sticking out too much).
summary.zh: Obtrusiveness 指“让人不舒服的过度显眼或唐突”，既可形容行为过于打扰、爱插手，也可形容外观过于突兀、碍眼。

definition.en: the quality of being too noticeable, pushy, or interfering in a way that makes others uncomfortable
